courses.condition: Prerequisite: CS 125 and CS 173; credit or concurrent enrollment in CS 225.

courses.name: System Programming
courses.detail: Basics of system programming, including POSIX processes, process control, inter-process communication, synchronization, signals, simple memory management, file I/O and directories, shell programming, socket network programming, RPC programming in distributed systems, basic security mechanisms, and standard tools for systems programming such as debugging tools.
courses.condition:
Credit is not given for both CS 241 and ECE 391. Prerequisite: CS 225; credit or concurrent registration in CS 233.
Students must register for one lecture and one discussion section.

courses.name: Programming Studio
courses.detail: Intensive programming lab intended to strengthen skills in programming.
courses.condition: Prerequisite: CS 241.

courses.name: Honors Course
courses.detail: Group projects for honors credit in computer science. Sections of this course are offered in conjunction with other 200-level computer science courses taken concurrently. A special examination may be required for admission to this course.
courses.condition: May be repeated. Prerequisite: Concurrent registration in another 200-level computer science course (see Schedule).

courses.name: Numerical Methods I
courses.detail: Fundamentals of numerical methods for students in science and engineering; floating-point computation, systems of linear equations, approximation of functions and integrals, the single nonlinear equation, and the numerical solution of ordinary differential equations; various applications in science and engineering; programming exercises and use of high quality mathematical library routines.
courses.condition: Same as MATH 357. Credit is not given for CS 357 if credit for CS 450 has been earned. (Counts for advanced hours in LAS). Prerequisite: A 100-level computer science course; MATH 225 or MATH 415; MATH 241.

courses.name: Probability & Statistics for Computer Science
courses.detail: Introduction to probability theory and statistics with applications to computer science. Topics include: visualizing datasets, summarizing data, basic descriptive statistics, conditional probability, independence, Bayes theorem, random variables, joint and conditional distributions, expectation, variance and covariance, central limit theorem. Markov inequality, Chebyshev inequality, law of large numbers, Markov chains, simulation, the PageRank algorithm, populations and sampling, sample mean, standard error, maximum likelihood estimation, Bayes estimation, hypothesis testing, confidence intervals, linear regression, principal component analysis, classification, and decision trees.
courses.condition: Same as STAT 361. Credit is not given for both CS 361 and ECE 313. Prerequisite: MATH 220 or 221; credit or concurrent registration in MATH 225. For majors only.

courses.name: Introduction to Algorithms & Models of Computation
courses.detail: Analysis of algorithms, major paradigms of algorithm design including recursive algorithms, divide-and-conquer algorithms, dynamic programming, greedy algorithms, and graph algorithms. Formal models of computation including finite automata and Turing machines. Limitations of computation arising from fundamental notions of algorithm and from complexity-theoretic constraints. Reductions, undecidability and NP-completeness.
courses.condition: Same as ECE 374. Prerequisite: CS 225; MATH 225 or MATH 415.

courses.name: Individual Study
courses.condition: May be repeated. Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.

courses.name: Database Systems
courses.detail: Examination of the logical organization of databases: the entity-relationship model; the hierarchical, network, and relational data models and their languages. Functional dependencies and normal forms. Design, implementation, and optimization of query languages; security and integrity; concurrency control, and distributed database systems.
courses.condition: 3 undergraduate hours. 3 or 4 graduate hours. Prerequisite: CS 225.

courses.name: Introduction to Data Mining
courses.detail: Concepts, techniques, and systems of data warehousing and data mining. Design and implementation of data warehouse and on-line analytical processing (OLAP) systems; data mining concepts, methods, systems, implementations, and applications.
courses.condition: 3 undergraduate hours. 3 or 4 graduate hours. Prerequisite: CS 225.

courses.name: Intro to Combinatorics
courses.condition: Same as MATH 413. See MATH 413.

courses.name: Interactive Computer Graphics
courses.detail: Basic mathematical tools and computational techniques for modeling, rendering, and animating 3-D scenes.
courses.condition:
Same as CSE 427. 3 undergraduate hours. 3 or 4 graduate hours. Prerequisite: CS 225; MATH 225 or MATH 415; MATH 241.
Students will register for a lecture and a discussion section.

courses.name: Parallel Progrmg: Sci & Engrg
courses.detail: Fundamental issues in design and development of parallel programs for various types of parallel computers. Various programming models according to both machine type and application area. Cost models, debugging, and performance evaluation of parallel programs with actual application examples.
courses.condition: Same as CSE 402 and ECE 492. 3 undergraduate hours. 3 or 4 graduate hours. Prerequisite: CS 225.

courses.name: Progrmg Languages & Compilers
courses.detail: Structure of programming languages and their implementation. Basic language design principles; abstract data types; functional languages; type systems; object-oriented languages. Basics of lexing, parsing, syntax-directed translation, semantic analysis, and code generation.
courses.condition: 3 undergraduate hours. 3 or 4 graduate hours. Prerequisite: CS 233 and CS 373.

courses.name: Unknown Course
courses.detail:
Unknown course.
Search courses.illinois.edu for more info
courses.condition: Unknown

courses.name: Real-Time Systems
courses.detail: Supervisory control aspects of Cyber Physical Systems (CPS): fundamentals of reliability analysis, real-time scheduling, simple feedback control, software fault tolerance architecture, wireless networking and energy saving, principles of safety critical system engineering. Student groups design and demonstrate supervisory control architecture for a robot.
courses.condition: 3 undergraduate hours. 3 or 4 graduate hours. Prerequisite: CS 241.

courses.name: Distributed Systems
courses.detail: Protocols, specification techniques, global states and their determination, reliable broadcast, transactions and commitment, security, and real-time systems.
courses.condition: Same as ECE 428. 3 undergraduate hours. 3 or 4 graduate hours. Prerequisite: CS 241 or ECE 391.

courses.name: Computer Systems Engineering
courses.detail: Concepts and abstractions central to the development of modern computing systems, with an emphasis on the systems software that controls interaction between devices and other hardware and application programs. Input-output semantics; synchronization; interrupts; multitasking; virtualization of abstractions. Term-based projects.
courses.condition: Credit is not given for both ECE 391 and CS 241. Prerequisite: ECE 220 or CS 233.

courses.name: Compiler Construction
courses.detail: Compiler structure, syntax analysis, syntax-directed translation, automatically constructed recognizers, semantic analysis, code generation, intermediate language, optimization techniques.
courses.condition: 3 undergraduate hours. 3 or 4 graduate hours. Prerequisite: CS 421.

courses.name: Software Engineering I
courses.detail: Software process, analysis and design. Software development paradigms, system engineering, function-based analysis and design, and object-oriented analysis and design. Course will use team-projects for hands-on exercises.
courses.condition: Same as CSE 426. 3 undergraduate hours. 3 or 4 graduate hours. Prerequisite: CS 225 and CS 373.

courses.name: Embedded Systems
courses.detail: A survey of sampled data systems and embedded architecture; key concepts in common embedded system applications; signal processing and control; embedded microprocessor and device interface; time-critical I/O handling; data communications; real-time operating systems and techniques for the development and analysis of embedded real-time software; hands-on laboratory projects.
courses.condition:
3 undergraduate hours. 3 or 4 graduate hours. Prerequisite: CS 241 or ECE 391.
Students must register for one lab and one lecture section.

courses.name: Computer System Organization
courses.detail: Computer system analysis and design. Organizational dependence on computations to be performed; speed and cost of parts and overall machines; instruction set design; pipeline and vector machines; memory hierarchy design.
courses.condition: Same as CSE 422. 3 undergraduate hours. 3 or 4 graduate hours. Prerequisite: CS 233.

courses.name: Communication Networks
courses.detail: Layered architectures and the OSI Reference Model; design issues and protocols in the transport, network, and data link layers; architectures and control algorithms of local-area, point-to-point, and satellite networks; standards in networks access protocols; models of network interconnection; overview of networking and communication software.
courses.condition: Same as ECE 438. 3 undergraduate hours. 3 or 4 graduate hours. Prerequisite: CS 241 or ECE 391; one of ECE 313, MATH 461, MATH 463.

courses.name: Probability with Engrg Applic
courses.detail: Probability theory with applications to engineering problems such as the reliability of circuits and systems to statistical methods for hypothesis testing, decision making under uncertainty, and parameter estimation.
courses.condition: Same as MATH 362. Credit is not given for both ECE 313 and MATH 461. Prerequisite: MATH 286 or MATH 415.

courses.name: Probability Theory
courses.detail: Introduction to mathematical probability; includes the calculus of probability, combinatorial analysis, random variables, expectation, distribution functions, moment-generating functions, and central limit theorem.
courses.condition: 3 or 4 undergraduate hours. 3 or 4 graduate hours. Credit is not given for both MATH 461 and either MATH 408 or ECE 313. 4 hours of credit requires approval of the instructor and department with completion of additional work of substance. Prerequisite: MATH 241 or equivalent.

courses.name: Wireless Networks
courses.condition: Same as ECE 439. See ECE 439.

courses.name: Artificial Intelligence
courses.detail: Major topics in and directions of research in artificial intelligence: AI languages (LISP and PROLOG), basic problem solving techniques, knowledge representation and computer inference, machine learning, natural language understanding, computer vision, robotics, and societal impacts.
courses.condition: Same as ECE 448. 3 undergraduate hours. 3 or 4 graduate hours. Prerequisite: CS 225 or ECE 391.

courses.name: Machine Learning
courses.detail: Theory and basic techniques in machine learning. Major theoretical paradigms and key concepts developed in machine learning in the context of applications such as natural language and text processing, computer vision, data mining, adaptive computer systems and others. Review of several supervised and unsupervised learning approaches: methods for learning linear representations; on-line learning, Bayesian methods; decision-trees; features and kernels; clustering and dimensionality reduction.
courses.condition: 3 undergraduate hours. 3 or 4 graduate hours. Prerequisite: CS 373 and CS 440.

courses.name: Numerical Analysis
courses.detail: Linear system solvers, optimization techniques, interpolation and approximation of functions, solving systems of nonlinear equations, eigenvalue problems, least squares, and quadrature; numerical handling of ordinary and partial differential equations.
courses.condition: Same as CSE 401, ECE 491, and MATH 450. 3 undergraduate hours. 3 or 4 graduate hours. Credit is not given for both CS 450 and CS 457. Prerequisite: CS 101 or CS 125; CS 357 or MATH 415; MATH 285.

courses.name: Computer Security I
courses.detail: Fundamental principles of computer and communications security and information assurance: ethics, privacy, notions of threat, vulnerabilities, and risk in systems, information warfare, malicious software, data secrecy and integrity issues, network security, trusted computing, mandatory and discretionary access controls, certification and accreditation of systems against security standards. Security mechanisms: authentication, auditing, intrusion detection, access control, cryptography, security protocols, key distribution.
courses.condition: Same as ECE 422. 3 undergraduate hours. 3 or 4 graduate hours. Prerequisite: CS 241 or ECE 391.

courses.name: User Interface Design
courses.detail: A project-focused course covering fundamental principles of user interface design, implementation, and evaluation. Small teams work on a term-long project that involves: analysis of the problem domain, user skills, and tasks; iterative prototyping of interfaces to address user needs; conducting several forms of evaluation such as cognitive walkthroughs and usability tests; implementation of the final prototype. Non-technical majors may enroll as non-programmers who participate in all aspects of the projects with the possible exception of implementation.
courses.condition: 3 undergraduate hours. 3 or 4 graduate hours. Prerequisite: CS 225.

courses.name: Introduction to Bioinformatics
courses.detail: Algorithmic approaches in bioinformatics: (i) biological problems that can be solved computationally (e.g., discovering genes, and interactions among different genes and proteins); (ii) algorithmic techniques with wide applicability in solving these problems (e.g., dynamic programming and probabilistic methods); (iii) practical issues in translating the basic algorithmic ideas into accurate and efficient tools that biologists may use.
courses.condition: 3 undergraduate hours. 3 or 4 graduate hours. Prerequisite: CS 225.

courses.name: Program Verification
courses.detail: Formal methods for demonstrating correctness and other properties of programs. Invariant assertions; Hoare axiomatics; well-founded orderings for proving termination; structural induction; computational induction; data structures; parallel programs; overview of predicate calculus.
courses.condition: 3 undergraduate hours. 3 or 4 graduate hours. Prerequisite: CS 225; CS 373 or MATH 414.

courses.name: Formal Software Devel Methods
courses.detail: Mathematical models, languages, and methods for software specification, development, and verification.
courses.condition: Same as ECE 478. 3 undergraduate hours. 3 or 4 graduate hours. Prerequisite: CS 225; CS 373 or MATH 414.

courses.name: Stochastic Processes & Applic
courses.condition: Same as IE 410. See IE 410.

courses.name: Applied Parallel Programming
courses.condition: Same as CSE 408 and ECE 408. See ECE 408.

courses.name: Seminar
courses.detail: Seminar on topics of current interest as announced in the Class Schedule.
courses.condition: 0 to 4 undergraduate hours. 0 to 4 graduate hours. Approved for S/U grading only. May be repeated in the same or separate terms if topics vary to a maximum of 4 hours. Prerequisite: As specified for each topic offering, see Class Schedule or departmental course description.

courses.name: Special Topics
courses.detail: Subject offerings of new and developing areas of knowledge in computer science intended to augment the existing curriculum. See Class Schedule or departmental course information for topics and prerequisites.
courses.condition: 1 to 4 undergraduate hours. 1 to 4 graduate hours. May be repeated in the same or separate terms if topics vary.

courses.name: Senior Thesis
courses.detail: Research and thesis development experience in computer science underguidance of a faculty member. Literature search, oral presentation, analysis and implementation, paper preparation, and completion of a written thesis.
courses.condition:
3 undergraduate hours. No graduate credit. May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours. Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.
This course satisfies the General Education Criteria in Fall 2016 for a UIUC: Advanced Composition course

courses.name: Scientific Visualization
courses.detail: Visualization techniques useful in analysis of engineering and scientific data. Physical models; methods of computational science; two- and three-dimensional data types; visual representation schemes for scalar, vector, and tensor data; isosurface and volume visualization methods; visual monitoring; interactive steering.
courses.condition: Same as CSE 527. Prerequisite: CS 418.

courses.name: Advanced Operating Systems
courses.detail: Advanced concepts in operating system design and coverage of recent research directions. Resource management for parallel and distributed systems. Interaction between operating system design and computer architectures. Process management, virtual memory, interprocess communication, context switching, parallel and distributed file system designs, persistent objects, process and data migration, load balancing, security, protection. Term projects.
courses.condition: Prerequisite: CS 423, CS 425, and CS 433.

courses.name: Topics in Software Engineering
courses.detail: Fault-tolerant software, software architecture, software patterns, multi-media software, and knowledge-based approaches to software engineering. Case studies.
courses.condition: Prerequisite: CS 428 or CS 429.

courses.condition: Same as ECE 541. See ECE 541.

courses.name: Models of Cognitive Processes
courses.detail: Formal models and concepts in automated cognition; integrating machine learning and prior knowledge; current approaches and detailed analyses of the role of reasoning in the learning process; computational complexity and fundamental tradeoffs between expressiveness and tractability; implications for state-of-the-art artificial intelligence areas such as automated planning, the semantic web, relational learning, structured prediction, latent models, structure learning, theory formation, etc.; philosophical and psychological aspects of integrating analytic and empirical evidence.
courses.condition: Same as ECE 548. Prerequisite: CS 440 or CS 446.

courses.name: Seminar in Cognitive Science
courses.condition: Same as PSYC 514, ANTH 514, EPSY 551, LING 570, and PHIL 514. See PSYC 514.

courses.name: Iterative & Multigrid Methods
courses.detail: Comprehensive treatment of algebraic and multigrid iterative methods to solve systems of equations, primarily linear equations arising from discretization of partial differential equations.
courses.condition: Same as CSE 511.

courses.name: Advanced Computer Security
courses.detail: Current research trends in computer and network security. Privacy, tamper-resistance, unwanted traffic, monitoring and surveillance, and critical infrastructure protection. Subtopics will vary depending upon current research trends. Students work in teams in close coordination with the course instructor to develop one of the topics in depth by carrying out background research and an exploratory project.
courses.condition: Same as ECE 524. Prerequisite: CS 461 or CS 463.

courses.name: Intro to Creative Writing
courses.detail: Acquaint students with the technical choices a writer makes in creating a story or a poem. Mondays are given to lectures on specific elements of poetry and fiction. Wednesdays are dedicated to readings by faculty and visiting writers. Fridays allow students the opportunity to work in small group discussion sections applying the week's techniques and skills to a close reading of stories and poems.
courses.condition: This course satisfies the General Education Criteria in Fall 2016 for a UIUC: Literature and the Arts course

courses.name: Introductory Narrative Writing
courses.detail: Practice in the writing of narrative prose, with primary emphasis on short fiction.
courses.condition: Prerequisite: Completion of campus Composition I general education requirement.

courses.name: Introductory Poetry Writing
courses.detail: Practice in the writing of poetry; experimentation with a number of fixed forms and free verse, but emphasis mainly on the student's freedom to develop a personal style.
courses.condition: Prerequisite: Completion of campus Composition I general education requirement.

courses.name: Reading for Writers
courses.detail: Emphasizes the craft of short stories and poems through the study of formal elements central to the production of creative writing (e.g., plot, character, setting, point of view in short fiction and rhythm, meter, line break, imagery, simile, metaphor, formal patterns in poetry).
courses.condition: Prerequisite: CW 104 or CW 106. For majors only.

courses.name: Topics in Creative Writing
courses.detail: Independent writing projects and examination of literature as the cultural basis of the student's specialized fields.
courses.condition: May be repeated as topics vary.

courses.name: Intermediate Narrative Writing
courses.detail: Practice in the writing of fiction, with emphasis on the short story.
courses.condition: Prerequisite: CW 104 or equivalent.

courses.name: Intermediate Poetry Writing
courses.detail: Builds upon the workshop format of CW 106, with an emphasis on prosody and poetic technique. Students will deepen their sense of craft by putting into practice their study and understanding of a variety of poetic forms (e.g., syllabic poetry, dramatic monologue, sonnet, bound/free verse) and technical concerns (e.g., voice, tone, line, line break, image). The workshop component of the course typically includes 8-12 completed poems and their revisions.
courses.condition: Prerequisite: CW 106.

courses.name: Creative Nonfiction Writing
courses.detail: Types of nonfiction prose, including the personal essay, memoir, literary journalism, and historical writing.
courses.condition: Prerequisite: RHET 233 or CW 243, or equivalent, or consent of instructor.

courses.name: Adv Rhetoric & Composition
courses.detail: Instruction in developing research-based arguments of moderate complexity within a special topics format. Introduction to the use of multimodal or other non-print resources as evidence in written arguments.
courses.condition:
Prerequisite: Completion of campus Composition I general education requirement.
This course satisfies the General Education Criteria in Fall 2016 for a UIUC: Advanced Composition course

courses.name: Inter Expository Writing
courses.detail: Practice in expository types, with emphasis on style and critical analysis. Restricted to Creative Writing majors.
courses.condition:
Credit is not given for CW 243 and either RHET 243 or RHET 233. Prerequisite: Completion of campus Composition I general education requirement.
Priority registration given to Creative Writing and English majors. Especially recommended for students who have some confidence in their handling of the fundamentals of writing.
This course satisfies the General Education Criteria in Fall 2016 for a UIUC: Advanced Composition course

courses.name: Advanced Narrative Writing
courses.detail: Continued practice in the writing of fiction, with emphasis on the longer story.
courses.condition: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 undergraduate hours or 8 graduate hours. Prerequisite: CW 204 or equivalent.

courses.name: Advanced Poetry Writing
courses.detail: Practice of the writing of poetry aided by intensive study of examples.
courses.condition: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated to a maximum of 6 undergraduate hours or 8 graduate hours. Prerequisite: CW 206 or equivalent.

courses.name: Creative Writing Tutorial
courses.detail: Personal direction in a writing project: fiction (novel or short stories), poetry or creative nonfiction. Frequency of conference to be determined by the type of project.
courses.condition: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated to a maximum of 6 undergraduate hours or 8 graduate hours. Prerequisite: CW 208, CW 404 or CW 406, and consent of the Director of Creative Writing.

courses.name: Intro to Literary Editing
courses.detail: Practicum in which students learn all the stages of developing and editing a literary publication. Students will solicit, read, and select poems and stories for an online supplement to the Ninth Letter literary journal. At the end of the semester, the supplement will be published on the Ninth Letter website (www.ninthletter.com). Students will gain experience in professional communications, copyediting, and marketing.
courses.condition: 3 undergraduate hours. No graduate credit. Prerequisite: CW 104 or CW 106.

courses.name: Adv Topics in Creative Writing
courses.detail: Advanced topics course in Creative Writing. Students study selected topic through a workshop model, pursuing advanced development in one or more approaches to writing in a specialized field or genre.
courses.condition: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated, if topics vary. Prerequisite: Junior standing required.

courses.name: The Craft of Fiction
courses.detail: Examination of the creative process of fiction from the perspectives of aesthetics and techniques, illustrated from the work of selected authors.
courses.condition: Prerequisite: Graduate standing in English.

courses.name: Problems in Poetry Writing
courses.detail: Examination of the creative process of poetry from the perspective of aesthetics and techniques, illustrated from the work of selected authors.
courses.condition: Prerequisite: Graduate standing in English.

courses.name: Writing Workshop in Fiction
courses.detail: Directed individual projects, with group discussion in fiction.
courses.condition: May be repeated to a maximum of 16 hours. Prerequisite: Admission to the MFA program, or graduate standing in English with advanced submission of creative work and consent of instructor.

courses.name: Writing Workshop in Poetry
courses.detail: Directed individual projects, with group discussion in poetry.
courses.condition: May be repeated to a maximum of 16 hours. Prerequisite: Admission to the MFA program, or graduate standing in English with advanced submission of creative work and consent of instructor.

courses.name: Independent Study
courses.condition: Approved for both letter and S/U grading. May be repeated up to a maximum of 12 hours. Prerequisite: MFA candidate standing.

courses.name: Final Project
courses.detail: Guidance in writing final projects.
courses.condition: Approved for S/U grading only. May be repeated in separate terms to a maximum of 12 hours. Prerequisite: MFA candidate standing.

courses.name: Bible as Literature
courses.condition:
Same as ENGL 114 and RLST 101. See RLST 101.
This course satisfies the General Education Criteria in Fall 2016 for a UIUC: Literature and the Arts course

courses.name: Global Consciousness and Lit
courses.detail: Exploration of the cultural and historical roots of globalization and the development of global consciousness from ancient Greece to the present, as reflected primarily in literature, but also with reference to historiography, cartography, religion, art, politics, economics, and popular culture. Course materials including literary texts, articles, historical accounts, political tracts, films, and paintings focus on the mutual perception of, and historical relationships among Europe, the Arab world, Africa, Asia, and the Americas.
courses.condition:
This course can be used to fulfill either Western or non-Western general education categories, but not both.
This course satisfies the General Education Criteria in Fall 2016 for a UIUC: Literature and the Arts course , and UIUC: Non-Western Cultures course , and UIUC: Western Compartv Cult course

courses.name: Russ & E Euro Science Fiction
courses.condition:

This course satisfies the General Education Criteria in Fall 2016 for a UIUC: Literature and the Arts course

courses.name: Literature of Fantasy
courses.condition: Same as ENGL 119. See ENGL 119.

courses.name: Cross-Cultural Thematics
courses.detail: Explores a combination of western and non-western literature through the focus on a shared theme, exploring differences in treatment both within and among different cultures. Two such thematic focuses are offered in rotation; one on concepts of love and one on ways of writing about death. Both themes introduce students to a wide array of famous texts from different cultures and also offer some varied perspectives for their own inevitable thoughts on these major topics.
courses.condition:
May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours if topics vary. Students may register in more than one section per term.
This course satisfies the General Education Criteria in Fall 2016 for a UIUC: Literature and the Arts course

courses.name: Freshman Honors Tutorial
courses.detail: Study of selected topics on an individually arranged basis. Open only to honors students or to Cohn Scholars and Associates.
courses.condition: May be repeated one time. Prerequisite: Consent of departmental honors advisor.

courses.name: Undergraduate Open Seminar
courses.detail: Credit: 1 to 5 hours.
courses.condition: Approved for both letter and S/U grading. May be repeated.

courses.name: Comparative Lit Studies
courses.detail: Introduction to various methods in comparative literary study, including genres, thematics, literary relations, literary movements, and interdisciplinary approaches.
courses.condition:
Prerequisite: One semester of college literature or consent of instructor.

courses.name: Lit Europe & the Americas I
courses.detail: Comparative study of major works from Europe and the Americas from ancient times to the Renaissance, emphasizing literary, cultural, and philosophical traditions, and cross-cultural contact. Authors studies may include Homer, Virgil, Dante, Petrarch, Cervantes, Las Casas, and Shakespeare.
courses.condition:
Prerequisite: Completion of campus Composition I general education requirement.
Students must register for one discussion and one lecture section.
This course satisfies the General Education Criteria in Fall 2016 for a UIUC: Literature and the Arts course , and UIUC: Western Compartv Cult course , and UIUC: Advanced Composition course

courses.condition:
Same as ENGL 206. See ENGL 206.
This course satisfies the General Education Criteria in Fall 2016 for a UIUC: Literature and the Arts course , and UIUC: Western Compartv Cult course

courses.name: Afro-American Literature I
courses.condition:
Same as AFRO 259 and ENGL 259. See ENGL 259.
This course satisfies the General Education Criteria in Fall 2016 for a UIUC: US Minority Culture(s) course

courses.name: Sex & Gender in Antiquity
courses.condition:
Same as CLCV 240 and GWS 240. See CLCV 240.
This course satisfies the General Education Criteria in Fall 2016 for a UIUC: Literature and the Arts course , and UIUC: Western Compartv Cult course

courses.name: The Short Story
courses.condition:
Same as ENGL 245. See ENGL 245.
This course satisfies the General Education Criteria in Fall 2016 for a UIUC: Literature and the Arts course

courses.name: The Holocaust in Context - ACP
courses.condition:
Same as ENGL 268 and GER 260. See GER 260.
This course satisfies the General Education Criteria in Fall 2016 for a UIUC: Literature and the Arts course , and UIUC: Western Compartv Cult course , and UIUC: Advanced Composition course

courses.name: Sexuality and Literature
courses.condition:
Same as GER 270 and GWS 270. See GER 270.
This course satisfies the General Education Criteria in Fall 2016 for a UIUC: Literature and the Arts course

courses.name: Masterpieces of East Asian Lit
courses.condition:
Same as EALC 275. See EALC 275.
This course satisfies the General Education Criteria in Fall 2016 for a UIUC: Literature and the Arts course , and UIUC: Non-Western Cultures course

courses.name: Japan Lit in Translation I
courses.condition:
Same as EALC 305. See EALC 305.
This course satisfies the General Education Criteria in Fall 2016 for a UIUC: Non-Western Cultures course , and UIUC: Literature and the Arts course

courses.name: Lit Responses to the Holocaust
courses.condition:
Same as ENGL 359, RLST 320, and YDSH 320. See YDSH 320.
This course satisfies the General Education Criteria in Fall 2016 for a UIUC: Literature and the Arts course , and UIUC: Western Compartv Cult course

courses.name: The Comic Imagination
courses.condition:
Same as CLCV 323 and THEA 323. See CLCV 323.
This course satisfies the General Education Criteria in Fall 2016 for a UIUC: Literature and the Arts course , and UIUC: Western Compartv Cult course , and UIUC: Advanced Composition course

courses.name: Tolstoy
courses.condition: Same as RUSS 323. See RUSS 323.

courses.name: Children and Youth Literature
courses.condition: Same as EURO 376, GWS 376, and SCAN 376. See SCAN 376.

courses.name: Special Topics Comp Lit I
courses.detail: Presentation and discussion of subjects relating literature to other disciplines; topic varies.
courses.condition: May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours.

courses.name: African Diasporic Lit Americas
courses.condition:
Same as AFRO 400. See AFRO 400.
This course satisfies the General Education Criteria in Fall 2016 for a UIUC: US Minority Culture(s) course

courses.name: History of Translation
courses.condition: Same as CLCV 430, ENGL 486, GER 405, SLAV 430, SPAN 436, and TRST 431. See SLAV 430.

courses.name: Lit Genres and Forms
courses.detail: Structure and development of literary genres and forms in historical perspective (for instance, drama, parody and the grotesque, poetry, fables and fabulists, and modern fiction); essential international components and significant national variations of such genres and forms. Emphasis changes from term to term.
courses.condition: 3 undergraduate hours. 3 or 4 graduate hours. May be repeated to a maximum of 9 undergraduate hours or 12 graduate hours. Prerequisite: One year of college literature or consent of instructor.

courses.name: Senior Thesis and Honors
courses.detail: Independent research guided by tutor(s), leading to the writing of a comparative thesis. Intended primarily for candidates for honors in comparative literature, but open to other seniors.
courses.condition: 3 to 6 undergraduate hours. No graduate credit. May be repeated to a maximum of 12 hours.

courses.name: Special Topics in Comp Lit II
courses.detail: Selected literary topics of international significance in relation to other cultural expressions.
courses.condition: 3 undergraduate hours. 3 or 4 graduate hours. May be repeated to a maximum of 9 undergraduate or 12 graduate hours. Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.

courses.name: Theory of Literature
courses.detail: Major issues of literary theory, critical approaches, and comparative research.

courses.name: Sem Spanish-American Lit
courses.condition: Same as SPAN 535. See SPAN 535.

courses.name: Seminar in Literary Relations
courses.detail: Investigation of the impact of one literature upon another, or of some specific works upon others (the role of English literature in continental Europe, the influence of Russian novelists on French and German writers, etc.).
courses.condition: May be repeated to a maximum of 12 hours if topics vary.

courses.name: Seminar Lit Themes
courses.detail: Study of a theme or type (the Faust myth, the romantic hero, etc.) to discover its essential components in all the literatures studied and the significance of national variations. The subject of the seminar varies each term.
courses.condition: May be repeated to a maximum of 12 hours if topics vary.

courses.name: Thesis Research
courses.detail: Intended for students engaged in writing a thesis as a partial requirement for the M.A. or Ph.D. degree in comparative literature.
courses.condition: Approved for S/U grading only. May be repeated to a maximum of 8 graduate hours.

courses.name: Undergraduate Open Seminar
courses.condition: May be repeated.

courses.name: Intro to Contemporary Dance
courses.detail: Overview of major works, figures, and trends responsible for shaping dance as an evolving contemporary art form. The course will have lecture, viewing, discussion and experiential (studio participation) components.
courses.condition:
For non-dance majors.
This course satisfies the General Education Criteria in Fall 2016 for a UIUC: Literature and the Arts course , and UIUC: Western Compartv Cult course

courses.name: Modern Dance I
courses.detail: Introduction to basic dance technique and movement improvisation; the study of motion as an art, group relationships in improvisation, and discussion of choreographic ideas. For non-dance majors.
courses.condition:
May be repeated to a maximum of 8 hours.
Student costs for supplies and concert tickets: Approx. $30. Written assignments and concert attendance is required.

courses.name: Modern Dance II
courses.detail: Intermediate dance technique and improvisation. For non-dance majors.
courses.condition:
May be repeated to a maximum of 8 hours. Prerequisite: DANC 101 or consent of instructor.
Student costs for supplies and concert tickets: Approx. $30. Written assignments and concert attendance is required.

courses.name: Contact Improvisation
courses.detail: Introduction to basic elements of Contact Improvisation through learning skills such as weight sharing, falling, rolling, responding to touch, momentum, gravity and disorientations. Course work will include dancing, dance making, viewing dance, in-class discussions and short writing assignments. Concert attendance is required.
courses.condition: May be repeated to a maximum of 8 hours. Prerequisite: For Non-dance majors.

courses.name: Making Dances
courses.detail: Introduction to basic choreographic elements. Course work will include dancing, dance making, viewing dance, in-class discussions and short writing assignments. Concert attendance is required.
courses.condition: May be repeated to a maximum of 8 hours. Prerequisite: For non-dance majors.

courses.name: Jazz Dance I
courses.detail: Introduction to basic dance technique and stylistic work in the jazz idiom.
courses.condition:
May be repeated to a maximum of 8 hours. Prerequisite: For non-dance majors.
Students with previous jazz dance experience should enroll in DANC 106. Student costs for supplies and concert tickets are approx. $30. Written assignments and concert attendance is required.

courses.name: Ballet I
courses.detail: Introduction to ballet for nondance majors.
courses.condition:
May be repeated to a maximum of 8 hours. Prerequisite: For non-dance majors.
Student costs for supplies and concert tickets are approx. $30. Written assignments and concert attendance is required.

courses.name: Ballet II
courses.detail: Progressive development of the concepts and skills in DANC 107; for the non-dance major.
courses.condition:
May be repeated to a maximum of 8 hours. Prerequisite: Two semesters of DANC 107 or equivalent or consent of instructor. For non-dance majors.
Student costs for supplies and concert tickets are approx. $30. Written assignments and concert attendance is required.

courses.name: Ballet III
courses.detail: Intermediate level of Ballet technique for non-dance majors. Course is a continuation and development of the skills in DANC 108.
courses.condition:
May be repeated to a maximum of 8 hours. Prerequisite: Two semesters of DANC 108 or equivalent or consent of instructor. For non-dance majors.
Written assignments and concert attendance is required.

courses.name: Cultural Dance Forms
courses.detail: Provides students with the physical study of various world dance forms. Topics reflect specializations of faculty, such as Capoiera, African dance, Balinese dance, and Chinese forms.
courses.condition: May be repeated to a maximum of 4 hours in the same term and 8 hours in separate terms.

courses.name: Hip Hop
courses.detail: Hip-Hop dance technique will consist of the study and practice of Urban dance forms grounded in hip-hop culture. Students will explore the multiple dimensions of hip-hop dance as they train in the fundamentals of each form, learn its respective historical context, and access ways of incorporating individual ideas and lived experiences into their dancing.
courses.condition: May be repeated in separate terms up to 8 hours.

courses.name: Tap Dance I
courses.detail: Introduction to basic tap technique for non-dance majors. Emphasis is on a conceptual understanding of tap style and the development of the specific skills needed for performance.
courses.condition:
May be repeated to a maximum of 8 hours. Prerequisite: For non-dance majors.
Written assignments and concert attendance is required.

courses.name: Production Practicum I
courses.detail: Practical experience in the production of dance concerts mounted in the Krannert Center for the Performing Arts.
courses.condition:
May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours. (1 hour credit per concert up to 2 hours per term).
Limited to dance majors.

courses.name: Orientation to Dance
courses.detail: Survey of the field including dance as a theatre art, careers, injury prevention and nutrition. Also serves to orient incoming students to the faculty, programs, and policies of the Department of Dance, and the production and performing resources in the Krannert Center for the Performing Arts.
courses.condition:
Prerequisite: Major standing in Dance or consent of instructor.
Limited to dance majors.

courses.name: Beg Contemp Modern Tech Core
courses.detail: Elementary technique for majors with emphasis on a conceptual understanding of movement principles and the development of technical skill and performance sensitivity.
courses.condition:
May be repeated to a maximum of 18 hours. Prerequisite: Major standing in Dance or consent of instructor.
Section placement assigned by the department. Non-dance majors admitted by audition on a space-available basis.

courses.name: Beginning Ballet Tech Core
courses.detail: Elementary ballet for dance majors; emphasizes placement, refinement of adagio, pirouette, jumps, and connecting steps.
courses.condition:
May be repeated to a maximum of 8 hours. Prerequisite: Major standing in Dance or consent of instructor.
Non-dance majors admitted by audition on a space-available basis.

courses.name: Beginning Ballet Tech Elect
courses.detail: Elementary ballet for dance majors; emphasizes placement, refinement of adagio, pirouette, jumps, and connecting steps.
courses.condition:
May be repeated to a maximum of 8 hours. Prerequisite: Major standing in Dance or consent of instructor.
Non-dance majors admitted by audition on a space-available basis.

courses.name: Int Hip Hop Technique
courses.detail: Hip-Hop dance technique will consist of the study and practice of Urban dance forms grounded in hip-hop culture. Students will explore the multiple dimensions of hip-hop dance as they train in the fundamentals of each form, learn its respective historical context, and access ways of incorporating individual ideas and lived experiences into their dancing.
courses.condition: May be repeated in separate terms for a maximum of 8 hours. Prerequisite: For majors only.

courses.name: Int Tap Dance Technique
courses.detail: Introduction to basic tap technique for experienced dancers. Emphasis on a conceptual understanding of tap style and the development of the specific skills necessary for performance and teaching.
courses.condition: May be repeated to a maximum of 2 hours. Prerequisite: Major standing in Dance, or consent of instructor

courses.name: Production Practicum II
courses.detail: Practical experience in the production of dance concerts mounted in the Krannert Center for the Performing Arts.
courses.condition:
May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours. (1 hour credit per concert up to 2 hours per term).
Limited to dance majors.

courses.name: Repertory Company
courses.detail: Provides dance majors with diverse performing experiences in the community. Venues will include area schools, nursing homes, and special populations. Students will participate in the creation of lecture-demonstrations which may include improvisation and choreography. Participation in all performances is a requirement.
courses.condition: May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours. Prerequisite: Major standing in Dance or consent of instructor.

courses.name: Dance History
courses.detail: Introduction to major artistic movements in dance history from ancient Greece through the 20th century. Goal of the course is to gain a broad understanding of dance in relation to socio-political ideologies of gender, race, sexuality, and national identities.
courses.condition: Prerequisite: Major standing in Dance or consent of instructor.

courses.name: Contact Improv for Act/Mus/Dan
courses.detail: In this interdisciplinary course, performing arts students learn physical skills necessary for the practice of the contact improvisation (CI) partnering dance form as well as improvisational and performance skills. Encourages contemplation of the broader philosophical implications inherent in the form: community building and accepting difference. Content includes visits to lectures and events outside the Dance Department.
courses.condition: May be repeated in separate terms to a maximum of 4 hours.

courses.name: Int Contemp Modern Tech Core
courses.detail: Progressive development of the concepts in DANC 160 and DANC 161, with emphasis on the qualitative and definitive performance of a variety of technical styles.
courses.condition:
May be repeated to a maximum of 18 hours. Prerequisite: Major standing in Dance and successful completion of two semesters of DANC 160; or consent of instructor.
Non-dance majors admitted by audition on a space-available basis.

courses.name: Choreographic Process I
courses.detail: Theory and practice in principles of dance composition; emphasis on solo creative work using various approaches to composition.
courses.condition:
Prerequisite: DANC 163 or consent of instructor.
Limited to dance majors.

courses.name: Unknown Course
courses.detail:
Unknown course.
Search courses.illinois.edu for more info
courses.condition: Unknown

courses.name: Intermediate Ballet Tech Core
courses.detail: Intermediate ballet for dance majors; a progressive development of movement concepts and vocabulary in DANC 166 and DANC 167, with emphasis on technical development and extended movement combinations.
courses.condition:
May be repeated to a maximum of 8 hours. Prerequisite: Major standing in Dance and successful completion of two semesters of DANC 166 or DANC 167; or consent of instructor.
Non-dance majors admitted by audition on a space-available basis.

courses.name: Intermediate Ballet Tech Elect
courses.detail: Intermediate ballet for dance majors; a progressive development of movement concepts and vocabulary in DANC 166 and DANC 167, with emphasis on technical development and extended movement combinations.
courses.condition: May be repeated to a maximum of 8 hours. Prerequisite: Major standing in Dance and successful completion of two semesters of DANC 166 or DANC 167; or consent of instructor.

courses.name: Yoga Practicum for Dancers
courses.detail: Introduces basic yoga asanas (postures) and brief overview of the 8-limb system of yoga. Focus will be on understanding correct alignment and developing inner awareness. Weekly home practice, journal, and discussions about yoga philosophy are required.
courses.condition: May be repeated in separate terms to a maximum of 8 hours.

courses.name: World Dance Forms
courses.detail: Provides students with the physical study of various world dance forms. Topics reflect specializations of faculty, such as Capoiera, African dance, Balinese dance, and Chinese forms.
courses.condition: May be repeated in the same term to a maximum of 2 hours. May be repeated in separate terms to a maximum of 8 hours. Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.

courses.name: Dance Documentation
courses.detail: This is a hands-on course for students interested in exploring the relationship between dance and camera and the fundamentals of dance documentation. Using critical and experiential approach, we will explore the technical and artistic capabilities of mini-DV cameras and film-editing software to create dance performance documentation. Students will learn to execute clear and effective camerawork in relationship to dance performance, and to utilize editing software to most clearly display the artistic intent of the choreographers and directors.
courses.condition: May be repeated up to 8 hours in separate terms. Prerequisite: For majors only, or by instructor approval.

courses.name: Production Practicum III
courses.detail: Practical experience in all aspects of the production of dance concerts mounted in the Krannert Center for the Performing Arts and within the Department of Dance.
courses.condition: May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours. (1 hour credit per concert up to 2 hours per term). Prerequisite: DANC 131, DANC 231 or equivalent, and consent of instructor.

courses.name: Dance Anatomy and Kinesiology
courses.detail: The study of human and anatomy and kinesiology, specifically as applied to dance. The human musculoskeletal system, movement analysis, and conditioning principles are covered both theoretically and practically.
courses.condition: This course satisfies the General Education Criteria in Fall 2016 for a UIUC: Life Sciences course

courses.name: Creative Dance for Children
courses.detail: Through lecture, discussion and practice, students develop skills to teach elements and concepts of dance to children ages 4-10. Course includes strategies for behavior and time management, spatial transitions, and how to organize and communicate creative concepts clearly and effectively. Students will observe master teaching and apply teaching techniques, acquire lesson plans that form the basis for a creative dance curriculum and the skills to implement them, and participate in all phases of a creative dance curriculum, including informal performance.
courses.condition: Same as ARTE 350 and HDFS 361. May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours. Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.

courses.name: Int/Adv Contemp Mod Tech Core
courses.detail: Progressive development of the concepts in DANC 260 and DANC 261, with emphasis on virtuosity and versatility.
courses.condition:
May be repeated to a maximum of 18 hours. Prerequisite: Major standing in Dance or consent of instructor; departmental placement.
Non-dance majors admitted by audition on a space-available basis.

courses.name: Choreographic Process II
courses.detail: Choreography for the experienced student; includes performance of at least one original work.
courses.condition: May be repeated to a maximum of 10 hours. Prerequisite: DANC 263 or consent of instructor.

courses.name: Unknown Course
courses.detail:
Unknown course.
Search courses.illinois.edu for more info
courses.condition: Unknown

courses.name: Advanced Improvisation
courses.detail: Exploration of the physical skills and philosophical concepts at the base of improvisation practice. Students will develop individual and collective approaches to improvisatory structures, systems and performance contexts as well as look at the historical ways that improvisation has been used in contemporary performance. The course will culminate in performance in various public and private contexts.

courses.name: Int/Adv Ballet Tech Core
courses.detail: Intermediate/Advanced ballet for dance majors; a progressive development of movement concepts and vocabulary in DANC 266 and DANC 267. For dancers of advanced technical level with the ability to execute the ballet vocabulary.
courses.condition: May be repeated to a maximum of 8 hours. Prerequisite: Major standing in dance or consent of instructor; or Departmental placement.

courses.name: Int/Adv Ballet Tech Elect
courses.detail: Intermediate/Advanced ballet for dance majors; a progressive development of movement concepts and vocabulary in DANC 266 and DANC 267. For dancers of advanced technical level with the ability to execute the ballet vocabulary.
courses.condition: May be repeated to a maximum of 8 hours. Prerequisite: Major standing in dance or consent of instructor; or Departmental placement.

courses.name: Viewing Dance
courses.detail: Overview of contemporary dance from the United States, Canada, and Europe focusing on the current works of significant emerging and established choreographers working in the field today.
courses.condition: 1 undergraduate hour. 1 graduate hour. Approved for S/U grading only. May be repeated to a maximum of 4 hours.

courses.name: Alexander Tech for Dancers
courses.detail: Introduces the Alexander Technique: a practical method for changing habitual movement patterns which interfere with coordination, ease, and efficiency of movement. The course focuses on learning the principles through hands-on work, readings, discussions, and application to dance. 1-3 individual lessons outside of class required per term.
courses.condition: 1 undergraduate hour. 1 graduate hour. Prerequisite: Major standing in Dance or consent of instructor.

courses.name: Alexander Technique Practicum
courses.detail: Facilitates conscious and reasoned control of the human organism as a psychophysical whole. Helps students recognize habits that constitute their daily activities and discard, through conscious control, those that impede open-minded enquiry and self-reliance. Through one-on-one work with certified teachers and trainees, students will learn to change habitual patterns of coordination.
courses.condition: 1 undergraduate hour. 3 graduate hours. May be repeated in separate terms to a maximum of 8 undergraduate hours or 6 graduate hours.

courses.name: Adv Hip Hop Technique
courses.detail: Advanced Level Hip Hop Class. Hip-Hop dance technique will consist of the study and practice of Urban dance forms grounded in hip-hop culture. Students will explore the multiple dimensions of hip-hop dance as they train in the fundamentals of each form, learn its respective historical context, and access ways of incorporating individual ideas and lived experiences into their dancing.
courses.condition: No undergraduate credit. 1 graduate credit. May be repeated in separate terms up to 8 hours. Prerequisite: For majors only.

courses.name: Dance Internship
courses.detail: Supervised field experience in community and/or professional organizations in a variety of danced-related areas. Provides students with work experience and exposure to professional situations. Written and/or video documentation and department presentation of internship activities required.
courses.condition: 1 to 4 undergraduate hours. 1 to 4 graduate hours. Approved for S/U grading only. May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours. Prerequisite: Major standing in Dance and consent of instructor.

courses.name: Production Practicum IV
courses.detail: Practical experience in all aspects of the production of dance concerts mounted in the Krannert Center for the Performing Arts and within the Department of Dance.
courses.condition: 1 or 2 undergraduate hours. 1 or 2 graduate hours. May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours. (1 hour credit per concert up to 2 hours per term). Prerequisite: DANC 131 or DANC 231, or equivalent and consent of instructor.

courses.name: Contact Improv Act/Mus/Dan II
courses.detail: An interdisciplinary course in which performing arts students learn physical skills necessary for the practice of the contact improvisation (CI) partnering dance form as well as improvisational and performance skills. Encourages contemplation of the broader philosophical implications inherent in the form: community building and accepting difference. Content includes visits to lectures and events outside the dance department.
courses.condition: 1 or 2 undergraduate hours. 1 or 2 graduate hours. May be repeated in separate terms to a maximum of 4 undergraduate hours or 6 graduate hours if topics vary.

courses.name: Adv Contemp Modern Tech Core
courses.detail: Modern technique for advanced graduate students.
courses.condition: 1 to 3 undergraduate hours. 1 to 3 graduate hours. May be repeated to a maximum of 16 hours. Prerequisite: Major standing in dance or consent of instructor; or departmental placement.

courses.name: Advanced Ballet Tech Elect
courses.detail: Ballet for advanced students.
courses.condition: 1 to 3 undergraduate hours. 1 to 3 graduate hours. May be repeated to a maximum of 16 hours. Prerequisite: Major standing in dance or consent of instructor or departmental placement.

courses.name: Senior Career Seminar
courses.detail: Addresses survival strategies and the transition from academe to the profession. Course content includes research and discussion of career possibilities in performance, choreography, teaching, community dance work, therapy, and the dance-related fields of health/fitness/recreation. Students will research individualized projects in an area of interest.
courses.condition: 1 undergraduate hour. No graduate credit. Prerequisite: Senior standing in Dance.

courses.name: Senior Thesis Production
courses.detail: The planning, design, and production of the Senior Capstone Project (DANC 499) for public performance. Students will work as a team to plan the Senior Concerts including designing and producing promotional materials and managing technical rehearsals and performances.
courses.condition:
1 or 2 undergraduate hours. No graduate credit. May be repeated in separate terms. Prerequisites: DANC 375. Concurrent enrollment in DANC 499 is required.
For Dance majors only. Senior standing in the major is required.

courses.name: Unknown Course
courses.detail:
Unknown course.
Search courses.illinois.edu for more info
courses.condition: Unknown

courses.name: Senior Thesis Project
courses.detail: The creation of a culminating choreographic/performance project.
courses.condition: 1 to 2 undergraduate hours. No graduate credit. Approved for S/U grading only. May be repeated to a maximum of 2 hours. Prerequisite: DANC 362 and senior standing in Dance. Concurrent enrollment in DANC 498 is required.

courses.name: Synthesis Laboratory
courses.detail: Required laboratory course focused on the practice of synthesizing expertise in choreography, physical practice, teaching, written and oral communication, and creative career planning. Critical theory and inquiry will be intertwined with rigorous examination of performance and construction of dance-making. Issues of sustaining practice, testing and conveying one's mission and vision, and elaborating on one's individual research in relationship to the field will be emphasized.
courses.condition: May be repeated up to 8 hours in separate terms. Spring and Fall terms, even years. Prerequisite: Graduate standing in Dance required.

courses.name: Contemporary Directions I
courses.detail: A critical approach to 20th century dance with emphasis on the evolution of ideas that have influenced and shaped the dance of today.
courses.condition: Prerequisite: Graduate standing in dance or consent of instructor.

courses.name: Creative Thesis Project
courses.detail: The design, implementation, and completion of a culminating creative project in choreography and/or performance.
courses.condition: Approved for S/U grading only. May be repeated to a maximum of 8 hours. Prerequisite: 28 hours of graduate work in dance, including 4 hours in choreography.

courses.name: East Asian Civilizations
courses.condition:
Same as HIST 120. See HIST 120.
This course satisfies the General Education Criteria in Fall 2016 for a UIUC: Non-Western Cultures course , and UIUC: Hist&Philosoph Perspect course

courses.name: Zen
courses.condition:
Same as RLST 132. See RLST 132.
This course satisfies the General Education Criteria in Fall 2016 for a UIUC: Non-Western Cultures course , and UIUC: Hist&Philosoph Perspect course

courses.name: Undergraduate Open Seminar
courses.condition: May be repeated.

courses.name: Traditional China
courses.condition:
Same as HIST 220. See HIST 220.
This course satisfies the General Education Criteria in Fall 2016 for a UIUC: Non-Western Cultures course , and UIUC: Hist&Philosoph Perspect course

courses.name: Intro to Japanese Culture
courses.detail: Topical introduction to Japanese cultural and aesthetic life with attention to cultural and aesthetic patterns as they are reflected in literature, language, and the arts.
courses.condition: This course satisfies the General Education Criteria in Fall 2016 for a UIUC: Non-Western Cultures course , and UIUC Social Sciences course

courses.name: Masterpieces of East Asian Lit
courses.detail: Study of major works in the literary traditions of China and Japan, including haiku, noh, Tale of Genji, kabuki, Tang poetry, Ming theater, and the colloquial tale.
courses.condition:
Same as CWL 275. No knowledge of Chinese or Japanese language required.
This course satisfies the General Education Criteria in Fall 2016 for a UIUC: Literature and the Arts course , and UIUC: Non-Western Cultures course

courses.name: Japan Lit in Translation I
courses.detail: Survey of Japanese literature from earliest times to 1600; readings in prose, poetry, and drama in English translation.
courses.condition:
Same as CWL 311.
This course satisfies the General Education Criteria in Fall 2016 for a UIUC: Literature and the Arts course , and UIUC: Non-Western Cultures course

courses.name: Individual Study
courses.detail: Directed readings in the languages and literatures of East Asia. The area selected depends on the student's interest.
courses.condition: May be repeated to a maximum of 8 hours. Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.

courses.name: Honors Tutorial
courses.detail: Tutorial in the civilizations of East Asia. The country and discipline depend on student interests. All students submit a substantial paper.
courses.condition: May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours. Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.

courses.name: Colloquium in EALC
courses.condition: May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours. Prerequisite: Junior standing.

courses.name: Soc-Econ Hist Modern China
courses.condition: Same as HIST 422. See HIST 422.

courses.name: Individual Study
courses.detail: Supervised individualized study of a topic not covered by regular course offerings. The topic must be approved by the instructor.
courses.condition: 3 to 12 undergraduate hours. 2 to 12 graduate hours. May be repeated to a maximum of 16 hours. Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.

courses.name: Proseminar in EALC
courses.detail: Interdisciplinary introduction for first-term East Asian Languages and Cultures graduate students to western-language writings on East Asia that have been important to modern scholarship on the region. The proseminar will cover the three cultures of the region in an interdisciplinary fashion, focusing on the methods of various disciplines in their treatment of East Asia. Method refers both to the kinds of materials studies, and the theory and tools used in research.

courses.name: Seminar in Chinese History
courses.condition: Same as HIST 521. See HIST 521.

courses.name: Seminar in EALC
courses.detail: Seminar on selected topics. Topic varies with instructor.
courses.condition: May be repeated to a maximum of 12 hours. Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.

courses.name: East Asian Language Pedagogy
courses.detail: Course is for teachers of Japan, Chinese, or Korean language who wish to improve their teaching skills and learn more about second and foreign language acquisition specific to the East Asian Language context. Besides reviewing research on language teaching methodology and curriculum development, students will observe each other conduct practice classes and analyze videotapes of class sessions.
courses.condition: Undergraduates may enroll with consent of instructor and the Graduate College. Prerequisite: Native or near-native fluency in Japan, Chinese, or Korean.

courses.name: Theories in SLA
courses.condition: Same as CI 584, EPSY 563, FR 584, GER 584, ITAL 584, LING 584, PORT 584, and SPAN 584. See SPAN 584.

courses.name: Individual Study and Research
courses.detail: Supervised individual investigation or study of a topic not covered by regular course offerings. The topic selected by the student and the proposed plan of study must be approved by the adviser and the instructor.
courses.condition: May be repeated. Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.

courses.name: Thesis Research
courses.detail: Research and guidance in writing theses for advanced degrees.
courses.condition: Approved for S/U grading only. May be repeated to a maximum of 16 hours. Prerequisite: Satisfactory completion of the preliminary examinations.

courses.name: Introduction to Computing
courses.detail: Introduction to digital logic, computer systems, and computer languages. Topics include representation of information, combinational and sequential logic analysis and design, finite state machines, the von Neumann model, basic computer organization, and machine language programming. Laboratory assignments provide hands-on experience with design, simulation, implementation, and programming of digital systems.
courses.condition: Credit is not given for both ECE 120 and CS 233. Prerequisite: Restricted to Computer Engineering or Electrical Engineering majors or transfer students with ECE Department consent.

courses.name: Undergraduate Open Seminar
courses.condition: Approved for both letter and S/U grading. May be repeated.

courses.name: Seminar
courses.detail: Discussions of educational programs, career opportunities, and other topics in electrical and computer engineering.
courses.condition: Approved for S/U grading only. For Computer Engineering and Electrical Engineering majors only.

courses.name: Intro to Differential Eq Plus
courses.detail: Techniques and applications of ordinary differential equations, including Fourier series and boundary value problems, linear systems of differential equations, and an introduction to partial differential equations. Covers all the MATH 285 plus linear systems. Intended for engineering majors and other who require a working knowledge of differential equations.
courses.condition:
Credit is not given for both MATH 286 and any of MATH 284, MATH 285, MATH 441. Prerequisite: MATH 241.
This course satisfies the General Education Criteria in Fall 2016 for a UIUC: Quant Reasoning II course

courses.name: Analog Circuits & Systems
courses.detail: Concepts from circuit and system analysis: linear systems; review of elementary circuit analysis; op amps; transient analysis; differential equation models of linear circuits and systems; Laplace transform.
courses.condition: Credit is not given for both ECE 211 and ECE 210. Prerequisite: ECE 110 and PHYS 212; credit or concurrent registration in MATH 285 or MATH 286.

courses.name: Individual Study
courses.detail: Individual projects. Approved written application to department as specified by department or instructors is required.
courses.condition: Approved for both letter and S/U grading. May be repeated in separate terms to a maximum of 2 hours. Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.

courses.name: Special Topics
courses.detail: Lectures and discussions relating to new areas of interest.
courses.condition: May be repeated in the same or separate terms for unlimited hours if topics vary. See class schedule for topics and prerequisites.

courses.name: Photonic Devices
courses.detail: Introduction to active and passive photonic devices and applications; optical processes in semiconductor and dielectric materials including electrical junctions, light emission and absorption, and waveguide confinement; photonic components such as light emitting diodes, lasers, photodetectors, solar cells, liquid crystals, and optical fiber; optical information distribution networks and display applications.
courses.condition: Prerequisite: PHYS 214.

courses.name: Digital Signal Processing
courses.detail: Introduction to discrete-time systems and discrete-time signal processing with an emphasis on causal systems; discrete-time linear systems, difference equations, z-transforms, discrete convolution, stability, discrete-time Fourier transforms, analog-to-digital and digital-to-analog conversion, digital filter design, discrete Fourier transforms, fast Fourier transforms, spectral analysis, and applications of digital signal processing.
courses.condition: Prerequisite: ECE 210.

courses.name: Digital Signal Processing Lab
courses.detail: Companion laboratory for ECE 310.
courses.condition: Prerequisite: Credit or concurrent registration in ECE 310.

courses.name: Probability in Engineering Lab
courses.detail: Designed to be taken concurrently with ECE 313, Probability in Engineering Systems, to strengthen the students' understanding of the concepts in ECE 313 and their applications, through computer simulation and computation using the Python programming language. Topics include sequential hypothesis testing, parameter estimation, confidence intervals, Bloom filters, min hashing, load balancing, inference for Markov chains, PageRank algorithm, vector Gaussian distribution, contagion in networks, principle component method and linear regression for data analysis, investment portfolio analysis.
courses.condition: Prerequisite: Concurrent enrollment in ECE 313 or one of: ECE 313, IE 300, STAT 410.

courses.name: Statistics and Probability II
courses.detail: Continuation of STAT 400. Includes moment-generating functions, transformations of random variables, normal sampling theory, sufficiency, best estimators, maximum likelihood estimators, confidence intervals, most powerful tests, unbiased tests, and chi-square tests.
courses.condition: Same as MATH 464. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Credit is not given for both STAT 410 and STAT 409. Prerequisite: STAT 400; or STAT 100 and MATH 461.

courses.name: Ethics and Engineering
courses.detail: Ethical issues in the practice of engineering: safety and liability, professional responsibility to clients and employers, whistle-blowing, codes of ethics, career choice, and legal obligations. Philosophical analysis of normative ethical theories. Case studies.
courses.condition:
Same as PHIL 316. Credit is not given for both ECE 316 and CS 210. Junior standing is required. Prerequisite: RHET 105.
This course satisfies the General Education Criteria in Fall 2016 for a UIUC: Hist&Philosoph Perspect course , and UIUC: Advanced Composition course

courses.name: Writing and Research
courses.detail: Introduction in research-based writing and the construction of academic, argumentative essays that use primary and secondary sources as evidence. This course fulfills the Campus Composition I general education requirement.
courses.condition:
Credit is not given for both RHET 105 and any of these other Comp I courses: RHET 101, RHET 102, CMN 111 or CMN 112.
Students whose second language is English should take an English placement test through the Division of English as an International Language, before signing up for rhetoric. Transfer students who have taken composition from another institution, but have not fully satisfied the U of I Comp I requirement can take the transfer writing test for proficiency credit. Engineering students must obtain a dean's approval to drop this course after the second week of instruction.
This course satisfies the General Education Criteria in Fall 2016 for a UIUC: Freshman Composition I course

courses.name: Fields and Waves I
courses.detail: Electromagnetic fields and waves fundamentals and their engineering applications: static electric and magnetic fields; energy storage; Maxwell's equations for time-varying fields; wave solutions in free space, dielectrics and conducting media, transmission line systems; time- and frequency-domain analysis of transmission line circuits and Smith chart applications.
courses.condition: Prerequisite: ECE 210.

courses.name: Power Ckts & Electromechanics
courses.detail: Network equivalents; power and energy fundamentals, resonance, mutual inductance; three-phase power concepts, forces and torques of electric origin in electromagnetic and electrostatic systems; energy conversion cycles; principles of electric machines; transducers; relays; laboratory demonstration.
courses.condition: Prerequisite: ECE 210.

courses.name: Green Electric Energy
courses.detail: Electric power grid structure and policy; analysis of wind, solar, and fuels as raw resources; wind turbines and parks; solar cells, modules, arrays and systems; fuel cell power plants; energy and financial performance of green energy projects; integration of green energy into power grid; energy project report and presentation.
courses.condition: Prerequisite: ECE 205 or ECE 210.

courses.name: Semiconductor Electronics
courses.detail: Modern device electronics: semiconductor fundamentals including crystals and energy bands, charge carriers (electrons and holes), doping, and transport, (drift and diffusion); unipolar devices with the MOS field effect transistor as a logic device and circuit considerations; basic concepts of generation-recombination and the P-N junction as capacitors and current rectifier with applications in photonics; bipolar transistors as amplifiers and switching three-terminal devices.
courses.condition: Prerequisite: ECE 210; PHYS 214; credit or concurrent registration in ECE 329.

courses.name: Electronic Circuits
courses.detail: Analysis and design of analog and digital electronic circuits using MOS field effect transistors and bipolar junction transistors, with emphasis on amplifiers in integrated circuits.
courses.condition: Credit is not given for both ECE 342 and PHYS 404. Prerequisite: ECE 210.

courses.name: Electronic Circuits Laboratory
courses.detail: Companion laboratory for ECE 342.
courses.condition: Credit is not given for both ECE 343 and PHYS 404. Prerequisite: Credit or concurrent registration in ECE 342.

courses.name: Fields and Waves II
courses.detail: Continuation of ECE 329: radiation theory; antennas, radiation fields, radiation resistance and gain; transmitting arrays; plane-wave approximation of radiation fields; plane-wave propagation, reflection, and transmission; Doppler effect, evanescent waves and tunneling, dispersion, phase and group velocities; waveguides and resonant cavities; antenna reception and link budgets.
courses.condition: Prerequisite: ECE 329.

courses.name: Introduction to Algorithms & Models of Computation
courses.condition: Same as CS 374. See CS 374.

courses.name: Biomedical Imaging
courses.detail: Physics and engineering principles associated with x-ray, computed tomography, nuclear, ultrasound, magnetic resonance, and optical imaging, including human visualization and perception of image data.
courses.condition: Same as BIOE 380. Prerequisite: MATH 285 or MATH 286.

courses.name: Digital Systems Laboratory
courses.detail: Design, build, and test digital systems using transistor-transistor logic (TTL), SystemVerilog, and field-programmable gate arrays (FPGAs). Topics include combinational and sequential logic, storage elements, input/output and display, timing analysis, design tradeoffs, synchronous and asynchronous design methods, datapath and controller, microprocessor design, software/hardware co-design, and system-on-a-chip.
courses.condition:
Prerequisite: ECE 110 and ECE 220.
Students must register for one lab and one lecture section.

courses.name: Advanced Digital Projects Lab
courses.detail: Planning, designing, executing, and documenting a microcomputer-based project. Emphasis on hardware but special projects may require an equal emphasis on software.
courses.condition: Prerequisite: ECE 385.

courses.name: Honors Project
courses.detail: Special project or reading course for James Scholars in engineering.
courses.condition: May be repeated. Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.

courses.name: Individual Study in ECE
courses.detail: Individual Projects.
courses.condition: Approved for both letter and S/U grading. May be repeated. Prerequisite: Consent of instructor. Approved written application to department as specified by department or instructor is required.

courses.name: Special Topics in ECE
courses.detail: Subject offerings of new and developing areas of knowledge in electrical and computer engineering intended to augment the existing curriculum. See Class Schedule or departmental course information for topics and prerequisites.
courses.condition: Approved for both letter and S/U grading. May be repeated in the same or separate terms if topics vary.

courses.name: Electronic Music Synthesis
courses.detail: Historical survey of electronic and computer music technology; parameters of musical expression and their codification; analysis and synthesis of fixed sound spectra; time-variant spectrum analysis/synthesis of musical sounds; algorithms for dynamic sound synthesis.
courses.condition: 3 undergraduate hours. 3 graduate hours. Prerequisite: MUS 103, ECE 290, and ECE 310.

courses.name: Rudiments of Music Theory I
courses.detail: Introduces non-music majors to basic terminology, technology, notation and  concepts of music, with a co-emphasis on digital audio.
courses.condition: Credit is not given for both MUS 103 and MUS 101.

courses.name: Unknown Course
courses.detail:
Unknown course.
Search courses.illinois.edu for more info
courses.condition: Unknown

courses.name: Applied Parallel Programming
courses.detail: Parallel programming with emphasis on developing applications for processors with many computation cores. Computational thinking, forms of parallelism, programming models, mapping computations to parallel hardware, efficient data structures, paradigms for efficient parallel algorithms, and application case studies.
courses.condition: Same as CS 483 and CSE 408. 4 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Prerequisite: ECE 220.

courses.name: Biomedical Instrumentation
courses.condition: Same as BIOE 414. See BIOE 414.

courses.name: Biomedical Instrumentation Lab
courses.condition: Same as BIOE 415. See BIOE 415.

courses.name: Embedded DSP Laboratory
courses.detail: Development of real-time digital signal processing (DSP) systems using a DSP microprocessor; several structured laboratory exercises, such as sampling and digital filtering; followed by an extensive DSP project of the student's choice.
courses.condition: 2 undergraduate hours. 2 graduate hours. Prerequisite: ECE 310.

courses.name: Computer Security I
courses.condition: Same as CS 461. See CS 461.

courses.name: Intro to VLSI System Design
courses.detail: Complementary Metal-Oxide Semiconductor (CMOS) technology and theory; CMOS circuit and logic design; layout rules and techniques; circuit characterization and performance estimation; CMOS subsystem design; Very-Large-Scale Integrated (VLSI) systems design methods; VLSI Computer Aided Design (CAD) tools; workstation-based custom VLSI chip design using concepts of cell hierarchy; final project involving specification, design, and evaluation of a VLSI chip or VLSI CAD program; written report and oral presentation on the final project.
courses.condition: 3 undergraduate hours. 3 graduate hours. Prerequisite: ECE 385 and ECE 411; or CS 233.

courses.name: Distributed Systems
courses.condition: Same as CS 425. See CS 425.

courses.name: Communication Networks
courses.condition: Same as CS 438. See CS 438.

courses.name: Wireless Networks
