courses.condition: Unknown

courses.name: Dynamical Systems I
courses.detail: An introduction to the study of dynamical systems. Considers continuous and discrete dynamical systems at a sophisticated level: differential equations, flows and maps on Euclidean space and other manifolds. Emphasis will be placed on the fundamental theoretical concepts and the interaction between the geometry and topology of manifolds and global flows. Discrete dynamics includes Bernoulli shifts, elementary Anosov diffeomorphisms and surfaces of sections of flows. Bifurcation phenomena in both continuous and discrete dynamics will be studied.
courses.condition: Prerequisite: MATH 489 or consent of instructor.

courses.name: Partial Differential Equations
courses.detail: Basic introduction to the study of partial differential equations; topics include: the Cauchy problem, power-series methods, characteristics, classification, canonical forms, well-posed problems, Riemann's method for hyperbolic equations, the Goursat problem, the wave equation, Sturm-Liouville problems and separation of variables, Fourier series, the heat equation, integral transforms, Laplace's equation, harmonic functions, potential theory, the Dirichlet and Neumann problems, and Green's functions.
courses.condition: Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.

courses.name: Linear Anal & Part Diff Eq
courses.detail: Course will provide students with the basic background in linear analysis associated with partial differential equations. The specific topics chosen will be largely up to the instructor, but will cover such areas as linear partial differential operators, distribution theory and test functions, Fourier transforms, Sobolev spaces, pseudodifferential operators, microlocal analysis, and applications of the above topics.
courses.condition: Prerequisite: MATH 447, MATH 489 or consent of instructor.

courses.name: Methods of Applied Mathematics
courses.detail: Introduction to modern methods of applied mathematics, including nondimensionalization and scaling analysis, regular and singular asymptotics, analysis of multiscale systems, and analysis of complex systems. Each technique is illustrated with applications from science and engineering. The mathematical frameworks will include ordinary, partial and stochastic differential equations, point processes, and Markov chains.
courses.condition: Prerequisite: Undergraduate background in ODEs, PDEs, and probability theory (MATH 441, MATH 442, and MATH 461, or equivalents), or consent of instructor.

courses.name: Theory of Probability II
courses.detail: Continuation of MATH 561.
courses.condition: Same as STAT 552. Prerequisite: MATH 561.

courses.name: Unknown Course
courses.detail:
Unknown course.
Search courses.illinois.edu for more info
courses.condition: Unknown

courses.name: Topics in Actuarial Theory I
courses.detail: Selected topics in advanced actuarial science.
courses.condition: May be repeated to a maximum of 16 hours. Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.

courses.name: Mathematical Logic
courses.detail: Development of first order predicate logic; completeness theorem; formalized number theory and the Godel incompleteness theorem.
courses.condition: Prerequisite: MATH 417 or consent of instructor.

courses.name: Model Theory
courses.detail: Techniques for constructing models, including compactness and Lowenheim-Skolem theorems, unions of elementary chains, and omitting types construction; categorical theories; ultraproducts; saturated models; quantifier elimination; applications to algebraically closed fields, real closed fields, and other fundamental structures of mathematics.
courses.condition: Prerequisite: MATH 570 or consent of instructor.

courses.name: Combinatorial Mathematics
courses.detail: Fundamental results on core topics of combinatorial mathematics: classical enumeration, basic graph theory, extremal problems on finite sets, probabilistic methods, design theory, discrete optimization.
courses.condition: Same as CS 571. Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.

courses.name: Structure of Graphs
courses.detail: Structure of graphs and properties of special classes of graphs. Degree sequences and reconstruction, structure of k-connected graphs, Hamiltonian cycles and circumference, planar graphs and their properties, graph minors, cycle coverings, matroidal and algebraic aspects of graphs.
courses.condition: Prerequisite: MATH 580 or consent of instructor.

courses.name: Mathematical Internship
courses.detail: Full-time or part-time practice of graduate-level mathematics in an off-campus government, industrial, or research laboratory environment. Summary report required.
courses.condition: 0 graduate credit. No professional credit. Approved for S/U grading only. May be repeated in separate terms.

courses.name: Advanced Topics in Math
courses.condition: May be repeated in the same or separate semesters. Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.

courses.name: Reading Course
courses.condition: Approved for both letter and S/U grading. May be repeated in the same or separate terms to a maximum of 8 hours. Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.

courses.name: Literature Seminar in Math
courses.detail: Seminar on topics of current interest in mathematics. Students present seminars and discussions on various topics. See Class Schedule for current topics. Recommended for all Mathematics students.
courses.condition: Approved for both letter and S/U grading. May be repeated as topics vary. Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.

courses.name: Thesis Research
courses.condition: Approved for S/U grading only. May be repeated. Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.

courses.name: Issues in Business
courses.detail: MBA students are faced with a wide variety of issues in the work place. This course will introduce and encourage discussions related to careers transitions, leadership, ethics, and uses of technology in the work place. Guest lecturers and experts in their field will discuss different approaches to these issues and give students the opportunity to discuss strategies and practice skills that will prepare them for the business environment.
courses.condition: Additional fees may apply. See Class Schedule. Approved for S/U grading only. Prerequisite: Co-requisite MBA 501 and MBA 502.

courses.name: Foundations of Business I
courses.detail: Provides foundations in the form of principles, concepts, tools, and skills important both to the study of business and to the development of business acumen. Specific foundation topics include planning and measuring firm resources, economic theory of the firm, decision making under uncertainty, consumer behavior, financial management, business communication and computing.
courses.condition: May be repeated in the same term. Credit is not given for MBA 501 and either ACCY 500, BADM 520, BADM 572, or ECON 567. Prerequisite: Admission to the Master of Business Administration program.

courses.name: Foundations of Business II
courses.detail: Provides additional foundations in the form of principles, concepts, tools, and skills important both to the study of business and to the development of business acumen. Specific foundation topics include organizational theory and design, financial accounting and reporting, manufacturing and services processes, marketing management, business communications and computing.
courses.condition: May be repeated in the same term. Credit is not given for MBA 502 and either ACCY 500, BADM 509, BADM 520, or BADM 567. Prerequisite: Enrollment in good standing in the MBA program.

courses.name: Internship
courses.condition: Approved for S/U grading only. May not be repeated for credit. Prerequisite: Completion of first year of Master of Business Administration program.

courses.name: Special Projects
courses.detail: Individual projects selected by the student in consultation with a faculty member and approved by the executive officer of the program.
courses.condition: Approved for letter and S/U grading. May be repeated in the same or subsequent terms to a maximum of 12 hours. Prerequisite: Completion of first year of Master of Business Administration program.

courses.name: Molec & Cellular Laboratory
courses.detail: Introductory laboratory course focusing on basic techniques in molecular and cellular biology.
courses.condition:
Credit is not given for MCB 151 for students majoring in Molecular and Cellular Biology, or Integrative Biology. Prerequisite: Concurrent enrollment in MCB 150.
For further information: www.life.illinois.edu/mcb/151.

courses.name: Society and the Brain
courses.detail: Presents recent findings concerning the brain-society interaction. The facts will span many levels, from molecular and cellular interactions, to the functions of specific brain regions, and on to the behaviors of individuals, groups and societies. Intended to bring a broad range of neurobiological data and ideas into an interesting and relevant context.
courses.condition: This course satisfies the General Education Criteria in Fall 2016 for a UIUC: Life Sciences course

courses.name: Internship
courses.detail: Full-time or part-time internship at another University or an off-campus medical facility, research institute or other approved institution.
courses.condition: Approved for S/U grading only. May be repeated. Prerequisite: For MCB and Biochemistry majors only.

courses.name: Undergraduate Open Seminar
courses.condition: Approved for letter and S/U grading. May be repeated to a maximum of 10 hours.

courses.name: Human Anat & Physiol Lab I
courses.detail: Laboratory exploration of normal human anatomy and physiology and relevant disease processes for the following systems: tissue, skeletal, nervous, muscular, sensory, and endocrine. Previously dissected human cadavers are an important part of the learning experience in this course, but students will not dissect human cadavers. Neither animal dissection or animal use are elements of this course.
courses.condition: Prerequisite: Credit or concurrent enrollment in CHEM 101, CHEM 102, or equivalent; or consent of instructor.

courses.name: Exp Techniqs in Molecular Biol
courses.detail: Laboratory course emphasizing a range of molecular biology questions, and the experimental approaches and methodologies needed to answer these questions. Lectures will accompany labs to explain theoretical background and experimental rationale. Students who enter the University Fall 2011 or later are responsible for additional course-based tuition of $300 unless they are already paying differential tuition during the term of course enrollment.
courses.condition:
Additional fees may apply. See Class Schedule. Credit is not given for both MCB 251 and MCB 151. Prerequisite: Concurrent or prior enrollment in MCB 250 or consent of instructor.
For further information: www.life.illinois.edu/mcb/251.

courses.name: Exp Techniqs in Cellular Biol
courses.detail: Laboratory course emphasizing experimental techniques in cellular biology, cellular physiology, and developmental biology. Students who enter the University Fall 2011 or later are responsible for additional course-based tuition of $300 unless they are already paying differential tuition during the term of course enrollment.
courses.condition:
Additional fees may apply. See Class Schedule. Credit is not given for both MCB 253 and MCB 151. Prerequisite: Concurrent or prior enrollment in MCB 252 or consent of instructor.
For further information: www.life.illinois.edu/mcb/253

courses.name: Undergraduate Research
courses.detail: Students assist in and /or conduct research under faculty supervision in an MCB research laboratory. The topics and nature of the work will vary but will be defined as work conducted in MCB research laboratories. For each hour of course credit in fall and spring terms, the student will be expected to complete 5 hours of work in the lab as directed. 75-80 total hours would be the expectation for 1 credit hour during 15-16 week terms.
courses.condition: May be repeated to a maximum of 10 hours. Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.

courses.name: MCB Honors Discussion
courses.detail: Honors discussion section associated with MCB 250, MCB 252, and MCB 354. Concurrent enrollment in the appropriate lecture course is required.
courses.condition: May be repeated in separate terms to a maximum of 3 hours.

courses.name: MCB Honors Lab Discussion
courses.detail: Discussion section associated with the Honors lab sections of MCB 251 and MCB 253. Concurrent enrollment in the appropriate Honors lab section is required.
courses.condition: May be repeated in separate terms to a maximum of 2 hours.

courses.name: MCB Merit Program Discussion
courses.detail: Provides the extra earned credit hours for students enrolled in the Merit Program in MCB 250, MCB 252, or MCB 354.
courses.condition: Approved for letter and S/U grading. May be repeated up to 6 hours in a semester, to a maximum of 10 total hours. Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.

courses.name: Microbiology
courses.detail: Emphasizes fundamental concepts of microbiology, including nutrition, physiology, genetics, molecular biology, ecology and evolution of microorganisms, and their role in nature, human health and disease.
courses.condition: Credit is not given for both MCB 300 and MCB 100. Prerequisite: MCB 250 and credit or concurrent registration in MCB 252 or consent of instructor.

courses.name: Introduction to Neurobiology
courses.detail: Introduction to functional and organizational principles of the mammalian nervous system. Topics include the function of nerve cells, neural signaling, sensory and motor systems, learning and memory, attention, motivation, emotions, language, neural development and neurological disorders. A general introduction appropriate for all majors.
courses.condition: Same as NEUR 314. Prerequisite: Junior or senior standing.

courses.name: Genetics and Disease
courses.detail: Introduction of the structure, expression, and regulation of genes of higher eukaryotes with an emphasis upon animal cells. Specific topics will include chromatin structure and its relation to gene expression, regulation of gene expression during development, recombination, molecular genetic technologies, gene replacement therapy, and the molecular genetics of cancers.
courses.condition: Credit is not given for both MCB 316 and MCB 317. Prerequisite: MCB 150 and credit or concurrent registration in MCB 250 or consent of instructor.

courses.name: Special Topics Human Physiol
courses.detail: Selected topics in general physiology.
courses.condition: Prerequisite: Credit or concurrent registration in MCB 401; consent of instructor.

courses.name: Cell & Membrane Physiology
courses.detail: Cellular and molecular basis of physiological process with an emphasis on phenomena taking place at the membrane of cells and organelles (e.g., signal transduction, ion transport, synaptic transmission, nerve conduction, bioelectricity, synaptic plasticity.) Structure and function of biological membranes through a quantitative lens.
courses.condition: 3 undergraduate hours. 3 graduate hours. Prerequisite: MCB 252 or consent of instructor.

courses.name: Endocrinology
courses.detail: Physiology and biochemistry of the endocrine system and its hormones with special reference to vertebrates and to human endocrine disorders.
courses.condition: 3 undergraduate hours. 3 graduate hours. Prerequisite: MCB 252 or consent of instructor. One semester of biochemistry is recommended.

courses.name: Bacterial Pathogenesis
courses.detail: Emphasizes prokaryotes that cause important diseases in humans and other animals; host-parasite bacteriology; and chemistry and genetics of mechanisms of pathogenesis.
courses.condition: 3 undergraduate hours. 3 graduate hours. Prerequisite: MCB 300 and MCB 354, or consent of instructor.

courses.name: Bacterial Pathogens Laboratory
courses.detail: Laboratory study of methods of recognition and differentiation, diagnostic tests, and mechanisms of bacterial and viral pathogenesis. Topics include infections of the urinary tract, respiratory tract, gastrointestinal tract, and sexually transmitted diseases.
courses.condition: 2 undergraduate hours. 2 graduate hours. Prerequisite: MCB 300 and MCB 301 or consent of instructor.

courses.name: Food & Industrial Microbiology
courses.condition: Same as FSHN 471. See FSHN 471.

courses.name: Global Biosecurity
courses.detail: Designed to provide students with broad coverage of key areas of scientific, legal, social, ethical, and political aspects of biosecurity, emphasizing current problems and research in the areas of biodefense, emerging infectious diseases, synthetic biology, and other topics. In combination with related reading assignments, the weekly special topics-based seminar will integrate knowledge of modern biomedical research, advances in biotechnology, and natural and manmade biological threats with the skills to analyze and develop public policies and strategies for enhancing global biosecurity.
courses.condition:
1 undergraduate hour. 1 graduate hour. Prerequisite: MCB 150 or the equivalent or consent of instructor.
Taught in Combination lecture- and seminar-based format.

courses.name: Cell & Molecular Neuroscience
courses.detail: Designed as an in-depth foundation course for graduate and undergraduate students with strong neuroscience interests. Covers up-to-date cellular and molecular neurobiology (including basic principles of neuronal function, signaling, and plasticity) and introductory brain anatomy that underlie brain function and animal behaviors. Pathogenic mechanisms of neurological diseases and disorders from the latest research will be heavily explored.
courses.condition: Same as NEUR 461. 3 undergraduate hours. 3 graduate hours. Prerequisite: MCB 252, MCB 250 or equivalent, or consent of instructor. May be taken concurrently with MCB 462.

courses.name: Unknown Course
courses.detail:
Unknown course.
Search courses.illinois.edu for more info
courses.condition: Unknown

courses.name: Advanced Cell Biology
courses.detail: Molecular basis of cellular organization focusing on how cells secrete, move, adhere, divide, communicate, and die. Material will emphasize critical analysis of experiments, current controversies and hypothesis testing.
courses.condition: 3 undergraduate hours. 3 graduate hours. Prerequisite: MCB 250 and MCB 252 or consent of instructor. Prior or concurrent enrollment in MCB 354 desirable.

courses.name: Senior Thesis
courses.detail: Research conducted under the direction of a faculty member in the School of Molecular and Cellular Biology. Normally, the student enrolls in MCB 492 during the last semester on campus prior to graduation. In the semester preceding enrollment, interested students should consult with their faculty advisors concerning enrollment procedures. A minimum of 3 credit hours is required, and a thesis must be presented for credit to be received. Successful completion of MCB 492 is required in order to be eligible for graduation with distinction in MCB.
courses.condition: 3 to 5 undergraduate hours. No graduate credit. Prerequisite: Two consecutive semesters of at least 2 credit hours of MCB 290 under the guidance of the same faculty member, or consent of instructor.

courses.name: Special Topics Mol Cell Biol
courses.detail: Discussion of current topics of interest within the broad domain of molecular and cellular biology; seminar or lecture format. Topics vary.
courses.condition: May be repeated to a maximum of 12 hours. Prerequisite: Junior standing and consent of instructor.

courses.name: Advanced Biochemistry
courses.detail: Focuses upon structure-function analyses of biomolecules and the chemical and evolutionary foundations of metabolic networks. Emphasis is on research methodology and current problems.

courses.name: Advanced Molecular Genetics
courses.detail: An advanced course in molecular genetics. Emphasis is on research methodology and current problems.

courses.name: Curr Topics Mol & Int Physiol
courses.detail: Advanced seminars in current physiological research.
courses.condition: May be repeated once for credit. Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.

courses.name: Adv Bacterial Pathogenesis
courses.detail: Advanced primary literature-based discussion course on bacterial pathogenesis. Graduate level companion course for MCB 426.
courses.condition: Prerequisite: Concurrent or prior enrollment in MCB 426 or consent of instructor.

courses.name: Special Topics Cell Devel Biol
courses.detail: Discussion of current topics of interest in higher eukaryotic cellular and molecular biology, development, neurobiology; seminar or lecture format. Topics vary.
courses.condition: May be repeated to a maximum of 8 hours. Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.

courses.name: Reproductive Physiol Seminar
courses.detail: Presentation and discussion of current literature as well as graduate student and staff research proposals and findings in reproductive physiology.
courses.condition: May be repeated to a maximum of 4 hours. Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.

courses.name: Repro Physiology Lab Methods
courses.condition: Same as ANSC 533 and CB 533. See ANSC 533.

courses.name: Scientific Writing
courses.detail: Study of scientific communication, geared toward biologists. Topics include writing mechanics, grammar and sentence structure, abstracts for different audiences and purposes, grant writing, manuscript preparation, figure construction, oral presentations, and the grant-review process. Class consists of both lectures and time working in small groups to revise writing assignments. Assignments include weekly writing exercises, a full NIH-style grant proposal and grant reviews for a mock study section.
courses.condition: 2 graduate hours. No professional credit.

courses.name: Anlys Biochemical Literature
courses.detail: Discussions of current research and literature. Required of all graduate students whose major is biochemistry.
courses.condition: Same as BIOC 555. Prerequisite: Second year graduate standing in biochemistry or consent of instructor.

courses.name: Mechanisms Viral Pathogenesis
courses.condition: Same as PATH 519. See PATH 519.

courses.name: Res Ethics & Responsibilities
courses.detail: Lecture/discussion course focusing on research ethics and a variety of related issues that can influence success in graduate school in the biological sciences, including scientific integrity and compliance with regulations for laboratory research.
courses.condition: Approved for letter and S/U grading. Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.

courses.name: Laboratory Rotation I
courses.detail: Laboratory research methods; familiarization of first-year graduate students with experimental methods used in molecular and cellular biology research. Required of all first-year students entering MCB. Meets first five weeks of each term.
courses.condition: Approved for S/U grading only. Prerequisite: First-year graduate status and consent of MCB graduate programs; concurrent registration in MCB 582.

courses.name: Laboratory Rotation II
courses.detail: Laboratory research methods; familiarization of first-year graduate students with experimental methods used in molecular and cellular biology research. Required of all first-year students entering MCB. Meets second five weeks of each term.
courses.condition: Approved for S/U grading only. Prerequisite: First-year graduate status and consent of MCB graduate programs; concurrent registration in MCB 581.

courses.name: Laboratory Rotation III
courses.detail: Laboratory research methods; familiarization of first-year graduate students with experimental methods used in molecular and cellular biology research. Required of all first-year students entering MCB. Meets third five weeks of each term.
courses.condition: Approved for S/U grading only. Prerequisite: First-year graduate status and consent of MCB graduate programs; concurrent registration in MCB 581 and MCB 582.

courses.name: College of Media Orientation
courses.detail: College of Media Orientation is designed to build academic and social integrity and to give students the resources they need to be responsible members of the University of Illinois community who earn degrees in a timely manner.

courses.name: Special Topics
courses.detail: Subject offerings of new and developing areas of knowledge and practice in the fields of media. The course is intended to augment the existing curriculum. See Class Schedule or college course information for topics and prerequisites.
courses.condition: Approved for letter and S/U grading. May be repeated in the same term to a maximum of 6 hours if topics vary; may be repeated in separate terms to a maximum of 12 hours if topics vary.

courses.name: Introduction to Media Sales
courses.detail: This course is guided by theory related to persuasion and social influence as it explores prevalent inter-personal and business-focused communication styles, methods and techniques used in the media sales industry. The course will cover the entire media sales cycle, from planning, to research, to setting sales objectives/strategies/goals and then how to effectively negotiate, "pitch" and "close" the sale, and evaluate and measure the sale once it is completed. It will consist of class lectures, in-class activities, role-playing exercises and also include guest lectures brought in from the sales industry.

courses.name: Undergraduate Open Seminar
courses.detail: Experimental course on special topics pertinent to the disciplines studied within the College of Media. Topics will vary.
courses.condition: Approved for letter and S/U grading. May be repeated in the same or separate terms to a maximum of 6 hours if topics vary.

courses.name: Media Study Abroad
courses.detail: Provides credit toward the undergraduate degree for study at accredited foreign institutions or approved overseas programs. Final determination of credit is made upon the student's completion of the work.
courses.condition: Approved for letter and S/U grading. May be repeated in separate terms to a maximum of 44 hours. Prerequisite: One year of residence at UIUC, good academic standing, and prior approval of the College of Media.

courses.name: Media Sales Management
courses.detail: This course addresses conceptual and methodological issues related to the management of sales within media organizations. Responsibilities, function and skills necessary to be an effective media sales manager are covered, including an evaluation of sales organization structures, recruiting, selecting, testing, and training of media salespeople. Related topics include compensation plans, controlling expenses, sales forecasting/projections, routing, quotas, ethics and motivation. It will consist of class lectures, in-class activities, role playing exercises and also include guest lecture from industry leaders/alumni with experience in media sales management.
courses.condition: Prerequisite: MDIA 270 (Introduction to Media Sales).

courses.name: Advanced Media Sales
courses.detail: This course focuses on consultative and persuasive selling and interpersonal relationship building, with an emphasis on specific media vehicles (broadcast, print, digital, out-of-home, non-traditional, etc.). It will discuss how to be a successful media salesperson for each medium (listed above), including major account selling, value-added selling, coordination between salespeople and the firm's other functional areas, team selling, negotiating, communication styles, career management, and personal development. The course will also cover the relationship between advertising agencies, advertising clients and salespeople. It will include mock interviews, written sales proposals, and role-playing exercises that will facilitate application of effective media sales techniques. It will also feature exposure to media sales experts for each medium covered in class.
courses.condition: Prerequisite: MDIA 270 (Introduction to Media Sales).

courses.name: 21st Century Documentaries
courses.detail: Documentary has exploded in the past decade, with more being created, screened and watched than at any time in history. But what has this growth meant to documentary, and how has it impacted what we see on screen and how documentary stories are being told? We will examine the changes and trends taking place in film and television documentaries over the past decade. We will watch and analyze a variety of contemporary documentaries, examining some of the different stylistic, production, and story-telling methods that have developed over this time. If you enjoy watching documentaries and want to learn more about them, you will find this an enjoyable and thought-provoking course.

courses.name: Special Topics in Media
courses.detail: Special topics course focusing on cultural, economic, historical, political, and social themes and issues that influence or are influenced by the media. Topics will vary.
courses.condition: Additional fees may apply. See Class Schedule. Approved for Letter and S/U grading. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 hours if topics vary. Prerequisite: One year of Media courses, Junior or senior standing in the College of Media, or consent of instructor.

courses.name: Special Topics
courses.detail: Varying topics including the cultural, social, historical, legal, economic, political, and other issues that influence or are influenced by Media.
courses.condition: 1 to 3 undergraduate hours. 1 to 3 graduate hours. May be repeated in the same or separate terms to a maximum of 6 hours if topics vary. Prerequisite: Previous classes in either AGCM, ADV, JOUR, or MACS.

courses.name: Psycholinguistics
courses.condition: Same as LING 525 and PSYC 525. See PSYC 525.

courses.name: Proseminar I
courses.detail: Addresses the mass media of communications, their role as social institutions, and their control and support. Examines evolution of research on mass media content, audience, and effects.
courses.condition: Prerequisite: Consent of department.

courses.name: Special Topics
courses.condition: May be repeated in the same or in multiple semesters if topics vary.

courses.name: Thesis Research
courses.condition: Approved for S/U grading only. May be repeated to a maximum of 16 hours.

courses.name: Medieval Lit and Culture
courses.condition:
Same as CWL 253 and ENGL 202. See ENGL 202.
This course satisfies the General Education Criteria in Fall 2016 for a UIUC: Literature and the Arts course , and UIUC: Western Compartv Cult course

courses.name: Medieval Art
courses.condition: Same as ARTH 222. See ARTH 222.

courses.name: Italy Middle Ages & Renaiss
courses.condition:
Same as CWL 240 and ITAL 240. See ITAL 240.
This course satisfies the General Education Criteria in Fall 2016 for a UIUC: Literature and the Arts course

courses.name: Viking Mythology
courses.condition:
Same as CWL 251, RLST 251, and SCAN 251. See SCAN 251.
This course satisfies the General Education Criteria in Fall 2016 for a UIUC: Hist&Philosoph Perspect course , and UIUC: Western Compartv Cult course

courses.name: Introduction to Old English
courses.condition: Same as ENGL 407. See ENGL 407.

courses.name: Medieval Architecture
courses.condition: Same as ARCH 412. See ARCH 412.

courses.name: History of the French Language
courses.condition: Same as FR 417. See FR 417.

courses.name: Medieval Latin
courses.condition: Same as LAT 460. See LAT 460.

courses.name: Genesis in History
courses.condition: Same as RLST 504. See RLST 504.

courses.name: Seminar in Medieval Literature
courses.condition: Same as ENGL 514. See ENGL 514.

courses.name: Computer-Aided Design
courses.detail: Geometry and topology of engineered components: creation of engineering models and their presentation in standard 2D blueprint form and as 3D wire-frame and shaded solids; meshed topologies for engineering analysis and tool-path generation for component manufacture; ISO and ANSI standards for coordinate dimensioning and tolerancing; geometric dimensioning and tolerancing. Use of solid-modeling software for creating associative models at the component and assembly levels with automatic blueprint creation, interference checking, and linked bill of materials.
courses.condition:
Credit is not given for both ME 170 and GE 101.
Reserved for Mechanical Science and Engineering students. Students must register for one lab and one lecture section.

courses.name: Undergraduate Open Seminar
courses.condition: May be repeated.

courses.name: Design for Manufacturability
courses.detail: Introduction to DFM methodologies and tools; material selection (new and traditional materials); designing for primary manufacturing processes (cutting fundamentals, casting, forming, and shaping); designing with plastics (snap-fits, integral hinges, etc.); design for assembly (DFA); geometric dimensioning and tolerancing (GD&T).
courses.condition: Prerequisite: ME 170. ME and EM majors only.

courses.name: Heat Transfer
courses.detail: Principles and application of heat transfer by conduction, convection, and thermal radiation.
courses.condition:
Prerequisite: ME 310 or TAM 335.
Students must register for one lab and one lecture section.

courses.name: Engineering Materials
courses.detail: Structures of polymers, metals, and ceramics as the basis for their mechanical behavior. Manipulation of structure through such processes as heat treatment and solidification. Mechanisms of material failure in service (yielding, fracture, fatigue, creep, corrosion, and wear) and simple design techniques to avoid these failures. Strategies for materials selection in design.
courses.condition:
Credit is not given for both ME 330 and either CEE 300 or MSE 280. Prerequisite: CHEM 102 and TAM 251.
Students must register for one lab and one lecture section.

courses.name: Dynamics of Mechanical Systems
courses.detail: Dynamic modeling of mechanical components and systems; time-domain and frequency-domain analyses of linear time-invariant systems; multi-degree-of-freedom systems; linearization of nonlinear systems.
courses.condition:
Credit is not given for both ME 340 and either GE 320 or AE 353. Prerequisite: MATH 285 and TAM 212; credit or concurrent registration in ECE 205, ECE 206, and MATH 415.
Students must register for one lab and one lecture section.

courses.name: Signal Processing
courses.detail: Basic electromechanical techniques used in modern instrumentation and control systems. Use of transducers and actuators. Signal conditioning, grounding, and shielding. Analog and digital signal processing and feedback control methods with emphasis on frequency domain techniques. Frequency response of continuous and discrete systems.
courses.condition:
Credit is not given for both ME 360 and ABE 425. Prerequisite: ME 340.
Students must register for one lab and one lecture section.

courses.name: Mechanical Design I
courses.detail: Kinematics and dynamics of machinery, including analytical kinematics, force analysis, cam design and balancing. Application of elementary mechanics of solids to analyze and size machine components for stress and deflection. Finite-element analysis with emphasis on beam and plate models.
courses.condition: Prerequisite: ME 170, TAM 212, and TAM 251.

courses.name: Mechanical Design II
courses.detail: Design and analysis of machinery for load-bearing and power transmission. Consideration of material failure modes, including yielding, fracture, fatigue, and creep. Design and selection of machine elements: bolts, springs, rolling-element bearings, fluid-film lubrication, and power transmissions, including gears and friction drives.
courses.condition: Prerequisite: ME 330 and ME 370.

courses.name: Seminar
courses.detail: Lectures by faculty and invited authorities, concerning the ethics and practices of mechanical engineering/engineering mechanics, as well as its relationship to other fields of engineering, to economics, and to society. Offered fall term only.
courses.condition: Approved for S/U grading only.

courses.name: Refrigeration and Cryogenics
courses.detail: Theory of operation and design of equipment for production of low temperatures, from below ambient to near absolute zero; industrial, consumer, aerospace, medical, and research applications.
courses.condition: 3 undergraduate hours. 3 or 4 graduate hours. Prerequisite: ME 300, ME 310, and ME 320.

courses.name: Internal Combustion Engines
courses.detail: Theory and analysis of reciprocating internal-combustion engines; fuels, carburetion, combustion, exhaust emissions, detonation, fuel injection, and factors affecting performance; laboratory work on variables that affect performance.
courses.condition: 3 undergraduate hours. 3 or 4 graduate hours. Prerequisite: Credit or concurrent registration in ME 400 or ABE 466.

courses.condition: Unknown

courses.name: Viscous Flow & Heat Transfer
courses.condition: Same as AE 412. See AE 412.

courses.name: Intermediate Heat Transfer
courses.detail: Conduction heat transfer, radiation heat transfer, mass transfer, phase change, heat exchangers; numerical methods.
courses.condition: 4 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Prerequisite: ME 310 and ME 320.

courses.name: Failure of Engrg Materials
courses.detail: Material anisotropy and elasto-plastic properties at the crystal level; microstructural basis for fatigue, fracture, and creep in metals, polymers, and ceramics; failure mechanisms and toughening in composites; structure and behavior of metal-matrix composites, ceramic-matrix composites, and polymer composites.
courses.condition: 3 undergraduate hours. 3 or 4 graduate hours. Prerequisite: ME 330.

courses.name: Introduction to Robotics
courses.condition: Same as AE 482 and ECE 470. See ECE 470.

courses.name: Modeling Materials Processing
courses.detail: Manufacturing processes for metals and polymers; creation of process models based on momentum, heat, and mass transfer; model simplification by estimation and scaling; applications to casting, microstructure evolution, polymer molding and extrusion, and welding.
courses.condition: 3 undergraduate hours. 3 graduate hours. Prerequisite: ME 320 and ME 330.

courses.name: Computer-Aided Mfg Systems
courses.detail: The application of computer technology and operations research to manufacturing systems. Use of microprocessors for direct numeric control of machine tools, adaptive control and optimization, and integrated manufacturing systems. Applications of industrial robots.
courses.condition: 3 undergraduate hours. 3 or 4 graduate hours. Prerequisite: ME 350.

courses.name: Unknown Course

courses.condition: Unknown

courses.name: Computer Cntrl of Mech Systems
courses.detail: Microcomputer control of thermal and mechanical systems: sensors and transducers, signal transmission and conversion, and regulator actuation.
courses.condition: 3 undergraduate hours. 3 or 4 graduate hours. Prerequisite: ME 360 or ABE 425.

courses.name: Unknown Course
courses.detail:
Unknown course.
Search courses.illinois.edu for more info
courses.condition: Unknown

courses.name: Musculoskel Tissue Mechanics
courses.detail: Composition-structure-function relationships for musculoskeletal tissues, including bone, tendon, ligament, cartilage, and muscle; hierarchical structure of tissues from the macro- to nano-scales; relation of composition to mechanical properties of health and diseased tissue; experimental methods used to obtain mechanical properties.
courses.condition: Same as BIOE 482. 3 undergraduate hours. 3 or 4 graduate hours. Prerequisite: TAM 251.

courses.name: MEMS Devices & Systems
courses.condition: Same as ECE 485. See ECE 485.

courses.name: MEMS-NEMS Theory & Fabrication
courses.detail: Physical and chemical theory, design, and hands-on fabrication of micro- and nano-electromechanical systems (MEMS and NEMS); cleanroom fabrication theory, including general cleanroom safety, lithography, additive and subtractive processes, bulk and surface micromachining, deep reactive ion etching (DRIE), lithographic Galvanoformung Abformung (LIGA), packaging, scaling, actuators, and micro-nanofluids; fabrication of two take-home devices, such as piezoresistive sensors and microfluidic logic chips, that demonstrate advanced fabrication processing.
courses.condition: 4 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Prerequisite: PHYS 212.

courses.name: Honors Project
courses.detail: Special project or reading course for James Scholars in engineering.
courses.condition: 1 to 4 undergraduate hours. No graduate credit. May be repeated. Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.

courses.name: Independent Study
courses.detail: Independent study of advanced problems related to mechanical engineering.
courses.condition: 1 to 4 undergraduate hours. 1 to 4 graduate hours. May be repeated. Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.

courses.name: Special Topics
courses.detail: Subject offerings of new and developing areas of knowledge in mechanical engineering intended to augment the existing curriculum. See Class Schedule or departmental course information for topics and prerequisites.
courses.condition: 0 to 4 undergraduate hours. 0 to 4 graduate hours. May be repeated in the same or separate terms if topics vary to a maximum of 9 hours.

courses.name: Multiphase Systems & Processes
courses.detail: Dynamics and thermodynamics of multiphase and multicomponent systems with special relevance to air-pollution control and energy conversion; relaxation phenomena; general motion of systems of disparate elemental masses; diffusion in gravitational and electric fields, and boundary-layer motion with mass transport; dispersion and collection of particulate matter; transport with surface reactions.
courses.condition: Prerequisite: ME 404.

courses.name: Advanced Gas Dynamics
courses.detail: Theoretical gas dynamics; fundamental laws and basic equations for subsonic, transonic, and supersonic steady and unsteady flow processes.
courses.condition: Same as AE 510. Prerequisite: ME 410.

courses.name: Unknown Course
courses.detail:

courses.condition: Unknown

courses.name: Thermal Radiation
courses.detail: Fundamentals of radiant-energy transport in absorbing and nonabsorbing media; pyrometry; applications to selected problems involving combined energy-transport mechanisms.
courses.condition: Prerequisite: ME 420.

courses.name: Fatigue Analysis
courses.detail: Fatigue analysis methods for the design of structures and components: stress-life, strain-life, and crack-propagation approaches; multiaxial and high-temperature fatigue; interrelationship among material properties, geometry, and design methodology appropriate for a wide range of mechanical engineering components.
courses.condition: Prerequisite: ME 430.

courses.name: Control System Theory & Design
courses.condition: Same as ECE 515. See ECE 515.

courses.name: Robust Adaptive Control
courses.detail: Mathematical foundation for synthesis and analysis of adaptive control systems: Lyapunov stability theory; methods of direct and indirect model reference adaptive control; recent methods, such as L1 adaptive control, that enable adaptive control with desired transient and steady-stage performance specifications.
courses.condition: Prerequisite: Any of ECE 486, ECE 515, ECE 528, GE 424, ME 460.

courses.name: Mechanics of MEMS
courses.detail: Mechanics and dynamics of microelectromechanical systems (MEMS); scaling laws in electrostatics, magnetics, and fluidics; analytical models for thin-film growth and etching; effect of surface tension in small dimensions in relations to stability of MEMS during web fabrication; size effects on mechanical properties of MEMS materials; equations of motion for MEMS, involving coupled elastic and electric fields that give rise to nonlinear dynamical behavior; Mathieu behavior and chaotic systems.
courses.condition: Prerequisite: ME 485.

courses.name: Seminar
courses.detail: Presentation and discussion of significant developments in mechanical engineering.
courses.condition:
Approved for S/U grading only. May be repeated.
Required of all graduate students each semester, with the exception of doctoral candidates who have passed the preliminary examination.

courses.name: Interest Group Seminar
courses.detail: Seminars on current topics in mechanical science and engineering.
courses.condition: May be repeated in the same term if topics vary. May be repeated in separate terms.

courses.name: Independent Study
courses.detail: Independent study of advanced problems related to mechanical engineering.
courses.condition: May be repeated in the same term or in separate terms if topics vary to a maximum of 12 hours. Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.

courses.name: Special Topics
courses.detail: Subject offerings of new and developing areas of knowledge in mechanical engineering intended to augment the existing curriculum. See Class Schedule or departmental course information for topics and prerequisites.
courses.condition: May be repeated in the same or separate terms if topics vary.

courses.name: Thesis Research
courses.condition: Approved for S/U grading only. May be repeated.

courses.name: Individual Topics
courses.condition: Approved for S/U grading only. May be repeated. Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.

courses.name: Microbiology Graduate Seminar
courses.detail: Required of all graduate students whose major is microbiology.
courses.condition: Approved for S/U grading only. May be repeated. Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.

courses.name: Thesis Research
courses.condition: Approved for S/U grading only. May be repeated.

courses.name: Introduction to Leadership
courses.detail: This course introduces you to the personal challenges and competencies that are critical for effective leadership. You will learn how the personal development of life skills such as goal setting, time management, physical fitness, and stress management relate to leadership, officership, and the Army profession. The focus is on developing basic knowledge and comprehension of Army leadership dimensions, attributes and core leader competencies while gaining a big picture understanding of the ROTC program, its purpose in the Army, and its advantages for the student.

courses.name: Leadership Laboratory
courses.detail: Introductory practical application of military skills and leadership; includes basic military mountaineering and rappelling, first aid, individual marching and weapons familiarization. Field trip may be required.
courses.condition:
Approved for S/U grading only. May be repeated.
For First-Year Military Science students. Field trips required. Attendance at Physical Training three days per week.

courses.name: Individual Leadership Studies
courses.detail: Establishes a foundation in military land navigation and offensive tactics; Explores the dimensions of creative leadership strategies and styles by examining team dynamics and leadership theories; also explores military mountaineering.
courses.condition: Prerequisite: Class is only available to students who have less than 60 credit hours.

courses.name: Leadership Laboratory
courses.detail: Intermediate level practical application of military skills and leadership; includes mountaineering and rappelling, first aid, small unit marching, weapons firing, and physical fitness. Field trip required.
courses.condition:
Approved for S/U grading only. May be repeated.
For second-year military science students. Attendance at physical training three days per week.

courses.name: Leadership and Problem Solving
courses.detail: Fundamentals of small unit military operations including operations planning, military orders, troop leading procedures, small unit offensive and defensive operations. Includes field practical application.
courses.condition:
Prerequisite: Successful completion of MILS 101, MILS 102, MILS 201 and MILS 202 is required to enroll in MILS 301.
Examines basic skills that underlie effective problem solving.

courses.name: Leadership Laboratory
courses.detail: Advanced level practical application of military skills and leadership with emphasis on the student's ability to direct and supervise others; includes advanced land navigation, advanced first aid, platoon and company drill and ceremonies, and advanced communications procedures. Field trip required.
courses.condition:
Approved for S/U grading only. May be repeated.
For third-year military science students. Field trips required.

courses.name: Leadership Laboratory
courses.detail: Unique opportunity for advanced course students to fully plan, execute, and supervise the military training and activities of other military science students. Emphasis is on leadership, organizing and managing activities, decision making, and effective instructional techniques. Field trip required.
courses.condition: Approved for S/U grading only. May be repeated.

courses.name: Independent Study
courses.detail: Supervised reading and research in a selected area of Military Science.
courses.condition: May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours.

courses.name: Leadership and Management
courses.detail: Fundamentals of military law including Law of Land Welfare, the application of federal law to the military, and the military justice system. Examines ethics, values, and professional standards through case studies. Includes introductory instruction on training management.
courses.condition: Prerequisite: Successful completion of MILS 301 and MILS 302 is required to enroll in MILS 341.

courses.name: Unknown Course

Unknown course.

courses.condition: Unknown

courses.name: Individual Topics
courses.detail: For graduate students wishing to study individual problems or topics not assigned in other courses.
courses.condition: Approved for S/U grading only. May be repeated. Prerequisite: Approval of department.

courses.name: Seminars in Physiology
courses.detail: Advanced seminars on current topics of interest in physiology.
courses.condition: Approved for S/U grading only. May be repeated to a maximum of 8 hours. Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.

courses.name: Thesis Research
courses.detail: Research may be conducted under supervision of the thesis advisor in the following areas: (a) cellular and molecular physiology; (b) comparative physiology; (c) mammalian physiology; (d) human physiology; (e) endocrinology; (f) neurophysiology; (g) radiobiology; and (h) environmental and stress physiology.
courses.condition: Approved for S/U grading only. May be repeated.

courses.name: Materials in Today's World
courses.detail: Introduction to the field of materials science. Examination and demonstration of materials and their properties in the context of their use in everyday objects. Survey of the role materials have played and will continue to play in shaping society. Intended for non-engineering majors. Technical elective credit is not given to College of Engineering majors.
courses.condition: This course satisfies the General Education Criteria in Fall 2016 for a UIUC: Physical Sciences course

courses.name: Introduction to MatSE
courses.detail: Overview of MatSE as a basis for understanding how structure, property, and processing relationships are developed and used for different types of materials. Case studies of advances in new materials and processes illustrating the role of materials in modern society. Laboratory-discussion demonstrations and experiments. Design-team analysis or synthesis of objects that use materials creatively.

courses.name: Undergraduate Open Seminar
courses.condition: May be repeated to a maximum of 5 hours. May be repeated in the same term.

courses.name: Phases and Phase Relations
courses.detail: Understanding microstructure. Quantitative examination of phases (crystalline and non-crystalline structures) and the relationships between phases (phase diagrams). Commercial practices for producing desired microscopic phase configurations and macroscopic shapes (processing).
courses.condition: Credit is not given for both MSE 201 and MSE 280. Prerequisite: MSE 182; credit or concurrent enrollment in CHEM 104, MATH 231 and PHYS 211.

courses.name: Engineering Materials
courses.detail: Materials science and engineering of ceramics, electronic materials, metals and polymers. Bonding; crystallography; imperfections; processing and properties of semiconductors, polymers, metals, ceramics and composites; phase diagrams. Case studies.
courses.condition: Credit is not given for both MSE 280 and any of CEE 300, ME 330, MSE 201. Prerequisite: CHEM 102 and PHYS 211.

courses.name: Materials Laboratory I
courses.detail: Experiments using optical and scanning electron microscopy and various thermal and thermodynamic measuring techniques. Familiarization with laboratory test instruments.
courses.condition:
MSE 307 and MSE 308 are approved for General Education credit only as a sequence. Both courses must be completed to receive Advanced Composition credit. Prerequisite: Credit or concurrent registration in MSE 401 and either MSE 201 or MSE 280.
This course satisfies the General Education Criteria in Fall 2016 for a UIUC: Advanced Composition course

courses.name: Thermodynamics of Materials
courses.detail: Basic thermodynamic principles including energy, entropy, and free energy; macroscopic properties of hard and soft materials systems, such as equilibrium states, phases, and phase transitions. Application of phase diagrams. Statistical interpretation of thermodynamics on the atomistic level.
courses.condition: 3 undergraduate hours. 3 graduate hours. Credit is not given for both MSE 401 and CHEM 444 or PHYS 427. Prerequisite: MSE 201 or MSE 280; credit or concurrent registration in MATH 285.

courses.name: Introduction to Research
courses.detail: Fundamental tenets of research including an introduction to laboratory safety, constructing a hypothesis, and the design of experiments to test the hypothesis. Basics of mathematical modeling and statistical analysis of data, including the analysis of research data. Emphasis on exposure to the basic procedures comprising engineering communication and the importance of verbal and written communication.
courses.condition: Approved for Letter and S/U grading. May be repeated in separate terms.

courses.name: Independent Study
courses.detail: Individual study of any topic in materials science and engineering selected by the student and conducted under the supervision of a member of the faculty.
courses.condition: May be repeated to a maximum of 4 hours. Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.

courses.name: Synthesis of Materials
courses.detail: Fundamentals of the synthesis of materials. Principles of synthesis; processes, approaches, synthetic methodology and probes; methodologies in materials synthesis; polymerization, sol-gel processes, liquid and vapor phase synthesis, materials coupling reactions, and precursor-derived, radiation-induced and asymmetric synthesis.
courses.condition: 3 undergraduate hours. 3 graduate hours. Prerequisite: MSE 201; credit or concurrent registration in MSE 401.

courses.name: Thermal-Mech Behavior of Matls
courses.detail: Fundamentals of elastic, viscoelastic and plastic deformation of materials, elementary theory of statics and dynamics of dislocations; strengthening mechanisms; behavior of composites; fracture and fatigue behavior; fundamentals of thermal behavior: heat capacity, thermal expansion and conductivity; effects of thermal stress.
courses.condition: 3 undergraduate hours. 3 graduate hours. Credit is not given for both MSE 406 and either ME 430 or TAM 424. Prerequisite: MSE 206; credit or concurrent registration in MSE 401.

courses.name: Laboratory Studies in Materials Science and Engineering
courses.detail: Experiments include direct hands-on investigations or are performed through computational approaches. Laboratory experiences include both fundamental studies as well as investigations on more applied topics.
courses.condition: 1.5 undergraduate hours. 1.5 graduate hours. May be repeated if topics vary. Prerequisite: MSE 307 and MSE 308 or permission of instructor. Senior standing.

courses.name: Mechanical Behavior of Metals
courses.detail: Mechanical behavior of solids: crystal plasticity, dislocations, point defects and grain boundaries, creep and fatigue behavior, and fracture.
courses.condition: 3 undergraduate hours. 3 graduate hours. Prerequisite: MSE 406.

courses.name: Ceramic Processing
courses.detail: Microstructure development and processing of ceramic materials, with an emphasis on structure-property-processing relationships. Processing methodologies and their effects on microstructural development. Illustration and examination of several ceramic components within this context.
courses.condition: 3 undergraduate hours. 3 or 4 graduate hours. Prerequisite: MSE 420.

courses.name: Design of Engineering Alloys
courses.detail: Application of science and engineering principles to the design, selection, and performance of engineering alloys. Alloy classes, design, effect of alloying elements, relation to processing variables, and structure-property relationships; design project.
courses.condition: 3 undergraduate hours. 3 graduate hours. Prerequisite: MSE 401 and MSE 402.

courses.name: Unknown Course

courses.name: Plastics Engineering
courses.detail: Engineering characteristics of plastics; viscoelasticity, viscosity, yield, and fracture; reinforced polymers; processing; environmental considerations; applicability of technical data sheets; design (project); current advances.
courses.condition: 3 undergraduate hours. 3 graduate hours. Prerequisite: MSE 450.

courses.name: Unknown Course

courses.name: Mechanics of Composites
courses.detail: Behavior of composite materials and their use in engineering structures: behavior and properties of the constituent fibers and matrices, micromechanical predictions of composite properties, anisotropic elasticity, behavior of composite laminae, and classical lamination theory; fracture mechanisms, failure theories; behavior of composite plates and beams.
courses.condition: Same as AE 428 and TAM 428. 3 undergraduate hours. 3 graduate hours. Prerequisite: AE 321, CEE 300, ME 330, or MSE 406.

courses.name: Polymer Chemistry
courses.detail: Methods used to synthesize macromolecules. Descriptive and mechanistic organic chemistry as they relate to polymer synthesis.
courses.condition: Same as CHEM 480. 3 undergraduate hours. 3 or 4 graduate hours.

courses.name: Design and Use of Biomaterials
courses.detail: Characterization and use of biomaterials in medical applications. Concepts of biocompatibility in terms of structure and properties of materials and interactions between materials and proteins, cells, and tissue. Issues related to the design of biomaterials. Design of biomaterials to meet specific medical needs.
courses.condition: 3 undergraduate hours. 3 graduate hours. Prerequisite: Credit or concurrent registration in both MCB 252 and either CHEM 232 or MSE 403.

courses.name: Electron Microscopy
courses.detail: Theory and application of transmission electron microscopy and diffraction with emphasis on thin crystals; electron optics, interference phenomena, interpretation of images and diffraction patterns, specimen preparation.
courses.condition: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Prerequisite: MSE 405.

courses.name: Unknown Course
courses.detail:
Unknown course.
Search courses.illinois.edu for more info
courses.condition: Unknown

courses.name: Atomic Scale Simulations
courses.detail: Application of Monte Carlo and Molecular Dynamics techniques in primarily classical simulations to understand and predict properties of microscopic systems in materials science, physics, biology, and chemistry. Numerical algorithms, connections between simulation results and real properties of materials (structural or thermodynamic), and statistical and systematic error estimation using real simulation programs. Simulation project comprised of scientific research, algorithm development, and presentation.
courses.condition: Same as CSE 485 and PHYS 466. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Prerequisite: MSE 401; one of C, C++, or Fortran programming experience.

courses.name: Matl Select for Sustainability
courses.detail: Quantitative methods to optimize the selection of materials including traditional (minimize mass or volume, maximize performance) and sustainability (minimize energy consumption and CO2 emission during synthesis, maximize recyclability) goals. Tradeoff methods to optimize both via engineering design and materials selection for product lifetime, economic outlay and return, time dynamics and materials consumption, recycling, and disposal. Application of commercial software to optimize selections. For engineering and science majors only.
courses.condition: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

courses.name: Lab Safety Fundamentals
courses.detail: Key aspects of laboratory setups, operating procedures, and emergency preparedness measures necessary for the experimentalist.
courses.condition: Same as CHEM 494. 1 undergraduate hour. 1 graduate hour. Approved for S/U grading only.

courses.name: Independent Study
courses.detail: Individual study of any topic in materials science and engineering under the supervision of a member of the faculty.
courses.condition: 1 to 4 undergraduate hours. 1 to 4 graduate hours. May be repeated to a maximum of 4 hours. Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.

courses.name: Senior Thesis
courses.detail: Individual research in an area of materials science and engineering under the supervision of members of the staff.
courses.condition: 1 to 5 undergraduate hours. No graduate credit. May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours. Prerequisite: Grade point average of 3.0 and consent of instructor.

courses.name: Statistical Thermodyn of Matls
courses.detail: Atomistic concepts of statistical thermodynamics and their relationship to classical phenomenological thermodynamics. Application of the methods of statistical thermodynamics and statistical mechanics to describe the structure, phase behavior, and properties of both hard and soft materials.
courses.condition: Prerequisite: MSE 401.

courses.name: Hard Materials Seminar
courses.detail: Seminar on current research in science and engineering of hard materials; presentations by visiting lecturers, staff, and students.
courses.condition: Approved for S/U grading only. May be repeated.

courses.name: Soft Materials Seminar
courses.detail: Seminar on current research in the science and engineering of soft materials; presentations by visiting lecturers, staff, and students.
courses.condition: Approved for S/U grading only. May be repeated.

courses.name: Point and Line Defects
courses.detail: Formation and interactions of point and line defects in solids including metals, semiconductors, dielectrics, and ionic conductors. Theoretical treatment of thermal equilibrium and non-equilibrium conditions. Application to impurity diffusion, ion irradiation, dislocation generation and motion, ionic conductivity, and deep level electronic defects.
courses.condition: Prerequisite: MSE 401 or MSE 501; PHYS 460 or PHYS 560.

courses.name: Condensed Matter Physics
courses.detail: Bonding and structure of crystals; energy bands in insulators, semiconductors, and metals; electrical conductivity; optical properties; lattice vibrations; elasticity; point defects; dislocations.
courses.condition: 4 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Credit is not given for both PHYS 460 and MSE 304. Prerequisite: PHYS 435; PHYS 485 or PHYS 486.

courses.name: Unknown Course
courses.detail:

courses.name: Research Seminars
courses.detail: Discussions and lectures on current research under the direction of individual staff members.
courses.condition: Approved for S/U grading only. May be repeated. Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.

courses.name: Materials Colloquium
courses.detail: Presentation of (i) cutting-edge materials research by visiting lectures from academia as well as national and industrial research laboratories and (ii) some of the current research conducted in the Department.
courses.condition: Approved for S/U grading only. May be repeated.

courses.name: Independent Study
courses.detail: Individual study of any topic in materials science and engineering under the supervision of a member of the faculty.
courses.condition: May be repeated to a maximum of 4 hours. Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.

courses.name: Thesis Research
courses.condition: Approved for S/U grading only. May be repeated.

courses.name: Seminar in Music Education
courses.detail: Seminar for students preparing to enter student teaching. Students should enroll in the semester prior to student teaching.
courses.condition:
Approved for letter and S/U grading. Prerequisite: Music education majors or consent of instructor.
For seniors in music education who will student teach in the spring.

courses.name: Music Theory and Practice I
courses.detail: Fundamental theory including terminology and notation; visual analysis of music elements, procedures, and forms; written applications in short projects.
courses.condition:
Credit is not given for both MUS 101 and MUS 103. Prerequisite: Placement by examination.
Students must register for one discussion and one lecture section.

courses.name: Beginning Composition
courses.detail: Class instruction in contemporary compositional practice at the beginning stages.
courses.condition: May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours. Prerequisite: Consent of instructor on the basis of a student portfolio of composition submitted to the composition-theory faculty and accepted after evaluation.

courses.name: Aural Skills I
courses.detail: Beginning aural skills training in the areas of intervals, scales, chords, rhythm, melody, and harmony.
courses.condition: Students must register for one lab-discussion and one lecture section.

courses.name: Aural Skills II
courses.detail: Continuation of aural skills training from MUS 107. Development of performance, notational, and listening skills in the areas of rhythm, melody, harmony, counterpoint, and formal aspects of musical structure; emphasizes tonal pitch structures.
courses.condition:
Prerequisite: MUS 101 and MUS 107, or placement by examination.
Register for the lecture and one discussion section.

courses.name: Introd Art Mus: Intl Perspect
courses.detail: Surveys the history of European and American art music in an international context; examines major artistic styles, representative composers and works, and their relationship to pertinent non-western musical traditions and philosophies; reviews fundamental music concepts; strengthens aural analytical skills; familiarizes students with the music library, and research and writing techniques.
courses.condition:
Prerequisite: First year standing in music or consent of instructor.
Students must register for one lecture and one discussion section.

courses.name: English Diction
courses.detail: Phonetics applied to English song literature; individual clinical analysis and practice. To be taken with MUS 181.
courses.condition: Prerequisite: Freshman standing in voice or consent of instructor.

courses.name: Italian Diction
courses.detail: Phonetics applied to Italian song literature; class and individual clinical analysis and practice. To be taken with MUS 181.
courses.condition: Prerequisite: Freshman standing in voice or consent of instructor.

courses.name: French Diction
courses.detail: French pronunciation applied to French vocal literature; class and individual clinical analysis and practice. To be taken with MUS 181.
courses.condition: Prerequisite: At least one semester of French or equivalent required, sophomore standing in voice, or consent of instructor.

courses.name: Introd to the Art of Music
courses.detail: Provides non-music majors with basic listening skills, the ability to discuss music intelligently, and an acquaintance with many types of music.
courses.condition:
Prerequisite: For non-music majors only. Students must register for one lecture and one discussion section.
This course satisfies the General Education Criteria in Fall 2016 for a UIUC: Literature and the Arts course , and UIUC: Western Compartv Cult course

courses.name: Introduction to World Music
courses.detail: A survey of various musical traditions from different regions and peoples of the world.
courses.condition:
For music and non-music majors. Students must register for one discussion and one lecture section.
This course satisfies the General Education Criteria in Fall 2016 for a UIUC: Literature and the Arts course , and UIUC: Non-Western Cultures course

courses.name: String Instrument Class
courses.detail: Class instruction to enable students to demonstrate proper technique and a characteristic sound on two bowed string instruments (violin or viola, and cello or double bass) in order to teach, via demonstration, beginning string students toward their maximum technical and musical development.
courses.condition: May be repeated to a maximum of 4 hours. Prerequisite: For music education majors only, with two semesters required for music education string majors.

courses.name: Supp WW Inst: Clarinet
courses.detail: Class instruction in the fundamentals of playing and teaching the clarinet. Acquire knowledge on recommended instruments and equipment, maintenance procedures, and training materials.
courses.condition: Prerequisite: Intended for woodwind majors in the BME instrumental concentration.

courses.name: Supp WW Inst: Flute
courses.detail: Class instruction in the fundamentals of playing and teaching the flute. Acquire knowledge on recommended instruments and equipment, maintenance procedures, and training materials.
courses.condition: Prerequisite: Intended for music majors in the BME instrumental concentration.

courses.name: Supp WW Inst: Oboe
courses.detail: Class instruction in the fundamentals of playing and teaching the oboe. Acquire knowledge on recommended instruments and equipment, maintenance procedures, and training materials.
courses.condition: Prerequisite: Oriented for music majors in the BME instrumental concentration.

courses.name: Supp WW Inst: Saxophone
courses.detail: Class instruction in the fundamentals of playing and teaching the saxophone. Acquire knowledge on recommended instruments and equipment, maintenance procedures, and training materials.
courses.condition: Prerequisite: Intended for music majors in the BME instrumental concentration.

courses.name: Supp WW Inst: Bassoon
courses.detail: Class instruction in the fundamentals of playing and teaching the bassoon. Acquire knowledge on recommended instruments and equipment, maintenance procedures, and training materials.
courses.condition: Prerequisite: Intended for music majors in the BME instrumental concentration.

courses.name: Supp Brass Inst: Trumpet
courses.detail: Class instruction in the fundamentals of playing and teaching the trumpet. Acquire knowledge on recommended instruments and equipment, maintenance procedures, and training materials.
courses.condition: Prerequisite: Intended for brass majors in the BME instrumental concentration.

courses.name: Supp Brass Inst: Horn
courses.detail: Class instruction in the fundamentals of playing and teaching the horn. Acquire knowledge on recommended instruments and equipment, maintenance procedures, and training materials.
courses.condition: Prerequisite: Intended for music majors in the BME instrumental concentration.

courses.name: Supp Brass Inst: Trombone
courses.detail: Class instruction in the fundamentals of playing and teaching the trombone. Acquire knowledge on recommended instruments and equipment, maintenance procedures, and training materials.
courses.condition: Prerequisite: Intended for music majors in the BME instrumental concentration.

courses.name: Supp Brass Inst: Euph/Tuba
courses.detail: Class instruction in the fundamentals of playing and teaching the euphonium and tuba. Acquire knowledge on recommended instruments and equipment, maintenance procedures, and training materials.
courses.condition: Prerequisite: Intended for music majors in the BME instrumental concentration.

courses.name: Supp Percussion Instruments
courses.detail: Class instruction in the fundamentals of playing and teaching percussion instruments. Acquire knowledge on recommended instruments and equipment, maintenance procedures, and training materials.
courses.condition: Prerequisite: Intended for music majors in the BME instrumental concentration.

courses.name: Jazz Keyboard Studies I
courses.detail: Prepares the student (through class participation) to perform one jazz standard on a functional level. Includes basic technique, chord voicing, comping, and lead sheet realization with functional fluency in all keys. Furnishes the student with class instruction on piano, focusing on jazz and improvisational idioms. An in-depth study of overall instrument technique, eminent styles, and other performance practices relevant to jazz piano and improvisation.
courses.condition: Prerequisite: MUS 172 and MUS 173, or consent of the instructor.

courses.name: Grp Instr Pno for Mus Major I
courses.detail: Group instruction in beginning piano for music majors whose principal performing medium is voice, or an orchestral or band instrument. Study of simple piano literature, development of skills in technique, sight reading, harmonization, transposition, improvisation, and analysis.
courses.condition:
This is the first of two courses that addresses the keyboard competency policy for non-piano majors.
For school of music majors only.

courses.name: Unknown Course
courses.detail:
Unknown course.
Search courses.illinois.edu for more info
courses.condition: Unknown

courses.name: Applied Jazz Instruction
courses.detail: Instruction at the undergraduate level in voice or instruments normally associated with the jazz idiom.
courses.condition:
Additional fees may apply. See Class Schedule. May be repeated to a maximum of 16 hours. Prerequisite: Successful performance audition for the jazz faculty.
Non-music majors will be assessed a fee.

courses.name: Class Jazz Improvisation I
courses.detail: Examines the dynamics of group improvisation at a fundamental level. Techniques of individual melodic development, group melodic development, and group contouring will be discussed and practiced. Requires preparation of group improvisations using the blues, a 32-bar song form, and a modal form, as well as class presentations and group demonstrations of basic group improvisational techniques.

courses.name: Unit One Sem Instruct in Music
courses.detail: Experimental seminar courses to introduce non-music majors to contemporary ideas in music.
courses.condition:
Approved for letter and S/U grading. May be repeated to a maximum of 4 hours. Prerequisite: For non-music majors only.
For unit one students only.

courses.name: Grp Instr Pno for Mus Maj III
courses.detail: Continuation of skills introduced in MUS 173. Group instruction in intermediate piano for music majors whose principal performing medium is voice, or an orchestral or band instrument. Study of intermediate level solos and ensemble compositions, harmonization with chromatic chords, sight reading, transposition of four-voice works, improvisation, and learning of patriotic songs.
courses.condition:
Prerequisite: MUS 102 and MUS 108; MUS 173 or equivalent; or consent of instructor.
For school of music majors only. Must have completed MUS 102 or equivalent.

courses.detail:

courses.condition:

Open only to students who have passed a qualifying audition. Non-music majors will be assessed a fee.

Only open to students who have passed a qualifying audition. Non-music majors will be assessed a fee.

courses.name: University Orchestra
courses.condition: May be repeated. Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.
