courses.detail: Study of the analysis of behavior in one or a few subjects using advanced time series designs; includes making accurate and reliable assessment of objective behaviors and designing experiments that feature interpretable comparisons among interventions and credible generalizability to subjects, settings, and time periods other than those specifically studied. Classic and current exemplars of these designs are studied and critiqued in depth.
courses.condition: Same as EPSY 583.

courses.name: Seminar for Advanced Students
courses.detail: Seminar in the education of individuals with special needs; open only to persons who have been admitted for graduate study.
courses.condition:
Additional fees may apply. See Class Schedule. Approved for letter and S/U grading.
Some sections may require additional course fees.

courses.name: Field Study and Thesis Seminar
courses.detail: Planning field studies and thesis problems by graduate students; students present their studies at each of four stages: (1) the inception, delimitation, tentative design stage; (2) the proposed design stage; (3) the revised design stage; and (4) the final design stage. Students are expected to analyze all presentations critically.
courses.condition: May be repeated up to 8 hours. Prerequisite: Admission to graduate studies in Special Education or consent of instructor.

courses.name: Concepts and Issues in SPED I
courses.detail: Roles and competencies for special education leadership positions; includes literature critique, and preparation and presentation of a major review paper in an area of research interest.
courses.condition: Prerequisite: Admission to doctoral studies in Special Education or consent of instructor.

courses.name: Independent Study
courses.detail: Self-directive, independent study, that is, develops the individual's ability as an independent student and enables the student to pursue needed study in a field in which appropriate courses are not being offered during a given term.
courses.condition: May be repeated with approval. Prerequisite: Approval of study outline by advisor and the department head prior to enrollment.

courses.name: Thesis Research
courses.detail: Individual direction of research and thesis writing.
courses.condition: Approved for S/U grading only. May be repeated.

courses.name: Elementary Swahili I
courses.detail: Beginning standard Swahili; emphasizes grammar, pronunciation, reading and conversation in standard Swahili.
courses.condition: Same as AFST 231. Participation in language laboratory required.

courses.name: Intermediate Swahili I
courses.detail: Second-year Swahili with emphasis on developing conversational fluency; some readings on Swahili culture and customs.
courses.condition: Same as AFST 433. 4 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Prerequisite: One year of Swahili.

courses.name: Advanced Swahili I
courses.detail: Third-year Swahili with emphasis on conversational fluency and on increased facility in reading Swahili texts, including current newspaper prose and (East) African culture materials.
courses.condition: Same as AFST 435. 3 undergraduate hours. 3 graduate hours. Prerequisite: SWAH 404 or equivalent.

courses.name: Topics Swahili Lang & Lit I
courses.detail: Selected readings from modern Kiswahili authors, with a focus on novels, plays, and basic poetry illustrative of East African cultural issues and advanced level Kiswahili grammar, as well as development of expository writing skills.
courses.condition: Same as AFST 405. 3 undergraduate hours. 3 graduate hours. Prerequisite: SWAH 406.

courses.name: Mechanics in the Modern World
courses.detail: Freshman introduction to engineering mechanics and its role in modern engineering analysis and design. Project activity.

courses.name: Undergraduate Open Seminar
courses.condition: May be repeated.

courses.name: Mechanics for Technol & Mgmt
courses.detail: Engineering mechanics (statics, dynamics, solid mechanics, and fluid mechanics) and the role that mechanics plays in engineering analysis and design. For Technology and Management majors only.

courses.name: Statics
courses.detail: Forces, moments, and couples; resultants of force systems; equilibrium analysis and free-body diagrams; analysis of forces acting on members of trusses, frames, etc.; shear-force and bending-moment distributions; Coulomb friction; centroids, center of mass, moment of inertia, polar moment of inertia, and product of inertia; virtual work; hydrostatic pressure; applications of statics in design.
courses.condition:
Credit is not given for both TAM 211 and TAM 210. Prerequisite: PHYS 211; credit or concurrent registration in MATH 241.
Students must register for one discussion and one lecture section.

courses.name: Behavior of Materials
courses.condition:
Same as CEE 300. See CEE 300.
Students must register for one lab and one lecture section.

courses.name: Fund of Engrg Acoustics
courses.condition: Same as ECE 473. See ECE 473.

courses.name: Mechanics of Structural Metals
courses.detail: Micromechanisms at the atomic, single-crystal, and polycrystal levels and their use in explaining the deformation and failure characteristics of metals; elastic deformation, dislocation mechanics, plastic deformation and strengthening mechanisms, fracture mechanics and fracture mechanisms, fatigue, and creep; design criteria; special topics.
courses.condition: 3 undergraduate hours. 3 graduate hours. Prerequisite: CEE 300 or ME 330.

courses.name: Mechanics of Composites
courses.condition: Same as AE 428 and MSE 456. See MSE 456.

courses.name: Intermediate Fluid Mechanics
courses.detail: Analytical solution methods for problems involving ideal and real fluids: potential flow theory, boundary-layer theory; surface waves, vortex dynamics, and compressible flows.
courses.condition: 4 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Prerequisite: One of AE 312, ME 310, TAM 335.

courses.name: Cellular Biomechanics
courses.detail: Mechanics of biological cells and tissues: cell structure; mechanics of biomembranes; the cytoskeleton and cortex; dynamic cell processes; cell motility and control of cell shape and proliferation; experimental approaches and theoretical models.
courses.condition: Same as BIOE 461. 4 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Prerequisite: TAM 251.

courses.name: Computational Mechanics
courses.detail: Modercomputational mechanics: mappings and iterative methods; stability; convergence; consistency; numerical and symbolic solutions of ordinary and partial differential equations; finite-difference methods; the finite-element method; spectral methods. Applications to problems in solid mechanics, fluid mechanics, and dynamics.
courses.condition: Same as CSE 450. 3 undergraduate hours. 3 or 4 graduate hours. Prerequisite: CS 101 and MATH 285.

courses.name: Independent Study
courses.detail: Individual studies in any area of theoretical and applied mechanics.
courses.condition: 1 to 4 undergraduate hours. 1 to 4 graduate hours. May be repeated to a maximum of 12 hours, with a maximum of 8 hours in any one term. Prerequisite: consent of instructor.

courses.name: Senior Thesis
courses.detail: Thesis investigation of special subjects in mechanics, including theoretical or experimental research.
courses.condition: 3 undergraduate hours. No graduate credit. Prerequisite: Department and instructor approval required.

courses.name: Seminar
courses.detail: Lectures and discussion on current topics in theoretical and applied mechanics.
courses.condition: Approved for S/U grading only.

courses.name: Elastodynamics and Vibrations
courses.detail: Review of theory of multi-degree-of-freedom systems; problems in the free and forced vibration of continuous linear elastic structures, rods, beams, membranes, plates, and three-dimensional solid and fluid bodies; Lagrangian densities, Sturm-Liouville problems, time and frequency domains, damping, Green's functions, and elastic waves; propagation and modal analysis; modeling of damping in structures; response of complex structures.
courses.condition: Prerequisite: TAM 412, TAM 542, and TAM 551.

courses.name: Unknown Course
courses.detail:
Unknown course.
Search courses.illinois.edu for more info
courses.condition: Unknown

courses.name: Solid Mechanics I
courses.detail: Mechanics of elastic deformable bodies, based on the fundamental concepts of modern continuum mechanics: kinematics, balance laws, constitutive equations; classical small-deformation theory; formulation of initial boundary-value problems of linear elastodynamics and boundary-value problems of linear elastostatics; variational formulations, minimum principles; applications of theory to engineering problems.
courses.condition: Prerequisite: MATH 285.

courses.name: Viscoelasticity Theory
courses.condition: Same as AE 529. See AE 529.

courses.name: Inviscid Flow
courses.detail: Dynamics of fluids in the limit of zero viscosity: governing equations of motion, kinematics, and vorticity transport; general theory of irrotational flow, including two-dimensional potential flow, the complex potential, and three-dimensional potential flow; applications to thin airfoil theory and free streamline theory; inviscid flows with vorticity; vortex dynamics; water wave theory; aspects of inviscid compressible flow.
courses.condition: Prerequisite: MATH 285 and TAM 435.

courses.name: Experimental Fluid Mechanics
courses.detail: Methods and techniques for measurement and analysis of data used in experimental fluid mechanics: signal processing, electronics, and electro-optics; fluid mechanical properties; experimental signal processing; random data and signal analysis; analog and digital data processing; dynamic similarity, self-preservation; pressure measurement, thermal anemometry, and laser-Doppler velocimetry; flow visualization, particle-image velocimetry.
courses.condition: Prerequisite: TAM 531 or TAM 532.

courses.name: Unknown Course
courses.detail:
Unknown course.
Search courses.illinois.edu for more info
courses.condition: Unknown

courses.name: Fluid Mechanics Seminar
courses.detail: Weekly seminar on current research topics in turbulent and other complex flows: theoretical modeling, numerical analysis, computational techniques, and experimental investigations.
courses.condition: Approved for S/U grading only.

courses.name: Mathematical Methods I
courses.detail: Vector and tensor algebra and complex-variable methods; ordinary differential equations, qualitative questions of existence and uniqueness; analytic solution methods, numerical methods, power-series solution and special functions; eigenvalue problems, Green's functions, Laplace transforms, stability of solutions; engineering applications drawn from mechanics.
courses.condition: Prerequisite: MATH 285 and TAM 251.

courses.name: Advanced Continuum Mechanics
courses.detail: Unified treatment of modern continuum mechanics: mathematical preliminaries; review of kinematics and general balance laws; general theory of mechanical constitutive equations, including material constraints and material symmetry.
courses.condition: Prerequisite: TAM 551.

courses.name: Asymptotic Methods
courses.detail: Advanced methods of perturbation theory and asymptotic analysis, with examples drawn from classical dynamics, fluid mechanics, and wave propagation: asymptotics of integrals, singular perturbation theory (boundary layers, matched asymptotic expansions, and composite expansions), multiple scales, summation of series; special topics.
courses.condition: Prerequisite: MATH 446 and TAM 541.

courses.name: Fracture Mechanics
courses.detail: Unified analytical treatment of modern fracture problems: macroscopic theories used to determine the static strength of bodies containing cracks; Griffith criterion, linear-elastic fracture mechanics, elastic-plastic fracture mechanics models; small-scale yielding results and their implications; general yielding; interfacial fracture; fracture control; micromechanisms of fracture.
courses.condition: Prerequisite: TAM 424 or MSE 440; TAM 541; TAM 552.

courses.name: Unknown Course
courses.detail:

courses.condition: Unknown

courses.name: Advanced Independent Study
courses.detail: Analytical, experimental, or computational studies in one or more areas of theoretical and applied mechanics, including solid mechanics, behavior of materials, fluid mechanics, dynamics, applied mathematics, and computational science and engineering.
courses.condition: May be repeated. (Summer session, 1 to 4 hours). Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.

courses.name: Advanced Special Topics
courses.detail: Subject offerings of new and developing areas of knowledge in theoretical and applied mechanics intended to augment the existing curriculum. See Class Schedule or departmental course information for topics and prerequisites.
courses.condition: May be repeated in the same or separate terms if topics vary to a maximum of 12 hours.

courses.name: Thesis Research
courses.condition: Approved for S/U grading only. May be repeated.

courses.name: Creativity, Innovation, Vision
courses.condition: Same as ENG 333. See ENG 333.

courses.condition: Same as ENG 360. See ENG 360.

courses.detail: Subject offerings of innovation, creativity, technology and entrepreneurship intended to augment the existing curriculum. See class schedule or departmental course information for topics and prerequisites.

courses.condition: Same as ENG 461. See ENG 461.

courses.name: High-Tech Venture Marketing
courses.condition: Same as ENG 466. See ENG 466.

courses.name: Independent Study
courses.detail: Advanced projects related to Technology Entrepreneurship.
courses.condition: Approved for S/U grading only. 1 to 4 undergraduate hours. 1 to 4 graduate hours. May be repeated to a maximum of 3 undergraduate hours or 4 graduate hours in the same term if topics vary; may be repeated for an unlimited number of hours in separate terms. Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.

courses.name: Special Topics III
courses.detail: Subject offerings of innovation, creativity, technology and entrepreneurship intended to augment the existing curriculum. See class schedule or departmental course information for topics and prerequisites.
courses.condition: Additional fees may apply. See Class Schedule. 1 to 4 undergraduate hours. 1 to 4 graduate hours. May be repeated in the same or separate term if topics vary.

courses.name: Technol Innovation & Strategy
courses.condition: Same as ENG 565. See ENG 565.

courses.name: Finance for Engineering Mgmt
courses.condition: Same as ENG 566. See ENG 566.

courses.condition: Same as ENG 567. See ENG 567.

courses.detail: Subject offerings of innovation, creativity, technology and entrepreneurship intended to augment the existing curriculum. See class schedule or departmental course information for topics and prerequisites.
courses.condition: May be repeated in the same or separate terms for unlimited graduate hours if topics vary.

courses.name: Practicum I
courses.detail: Practical work in the design, construction, and handling of scenery, lighting, sound, properties, costumes, and makeup for public performance. A minimum of forty hours of production activity to be arranged for each credit hour.
courses.condition:
May be repeated to a maximum of 12 hours. Prerequisite: Consent of instructor required for non-theatre majors.
40 hours production activity to be arranged for each credit hour.

courses.name: Introduction to Theatre Arts
courses.detail: Introduction to the arts of theater for non-majors, including acting, design, directing, dramaturgy, and playwriting, together with a survey of theatrical history, minority theater, and plays by women. Attendance at Department of Theater productions (ticket fee required).
courses.condition:
Credit not given for both THEA 101 and THEA 102.
This course satisfies the General Education Criteria in Fall 2016 for a UIUC: Literature and the Arts course

courses.name: Text to Stage
courses.detail: Practical exploration of theatre production for Theatre majors with emphasis on the collaborative contributions of playwrights, actors, directors, designers, and dramaturges, culminating in final group projects in planning productions of one-act plays. Attendance at Department of Theatre productions required.
courses.condition:
Credit not given for both THEA 101 and THEA 102. This course is required for all Theatre Majors.
This course satisfies the General Education Criteria in Fall 2016 for a UIUC: Literature and the Arts course

courses.name: Broadway Musicals
courses.detail: A cultural context of the uniquely "American" Broadway musical through an introduction to the art form, an analysis of the pertinent time period, and historical and critical placement of the work as a reflection (and development) of the identity of the United States. This course will introduce the collaborative artistry of the musical, survey specific iconic works, and explore the socio-economic impacts of the Broadway musical. Attendance at selected performances is required.
courses.condition: This course satisfies the General Education Criteria in Fall 2016 for a UIUC: Literature and the Arts course , and UIUC: Western Compartv Cult course

courses.name: Fundamentals of Acting I
courses.detail: Study of the methods of acting, with emphasis on basic acting techniques; role of character in relation to the play as a whole, the play's internal and emotional values, and their interpretation through voice and action.
courses.condition: Some sections reserved for Theatre majors only, fall semester only.

courses.name: Undergraduate Open Seminar
courses.condition: Approved for letter and S/U grading. May be repeated to a maximum of 12 hours.

courses.name: Dramatic Analysis
courses.detail: Introduction to the study of plays for theatre practitioners employing analytical methods and plays from modern theatre. Requires paper or project assignments for each play.
courses.condition: Prerequisite: Consent of instructor required for non-theatre majors.

courses.name: Introduction to Playwriting
courses.detail: Practical course in writing for the stage, including a study of basic dramatic construction and the analysis of weekly writing assignments, focusing on structure, style, and imagination, and culminating in a final term project of a one-act play.
courses.condition: Prerequisite: THEA 208 or consent of instructor.

courses.name: Intro to Social Issues Theatre
courses.detail: An introductory exploration/survey of the rich histories, theories, and practices of community-based and social issues theatre. Through discussion, participation, lecture, and performance, representative works, movement, and artists will be explored. Lively connections will be made to an array of social issues in today's world.
courses.condition: Same as GWS 218.

courses.name: Survey of Theatrical Design
courses.detail: Survey of design elements in theatrical production including the function of scenery, costuming, lighting, and sound in conveying directorial concepts, style, and dramatic meaning. Intended for students not concentrating on theatrical design, this course requires both theoretical and practical projects.
courses.condition: Prerequisite: THEA 102, THEA 208, or consent of instructor.

courses.name: Intro to Lighting Design
courses.detail: Studio course analyzing current lighting practices and equipment by means of production oriented assignments.
courses.condition: Theatre Majors only.

courses.name: Intro African American Theat
courses.detail: Focuses on theatre artists, theatre companies, and the role of Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCU's). Students will read plays, view productions, screen documentaries, and examine various primary sources.
courses.condition:
Same as AFRO 212.
This course satisfies the General Education Criteria in Fall 2016 for a UIUC: US Minority Culture(s) course

courses.name: Relationships in Acting I
courses.detail: Behavior in stage performance explored on the basis of the actor's relationship with self, with objects, and with other players; emphasizes analysis of playscript to discover action, environment, and relationships.
courses.condition: Prerequisite: THEA 175 or consent of instructor.

courses.name: Voice and Movement I
courses.detail: Fundamental development of vocal production as connected to body awareness and movement for the actor. Various exercised, conditioning, and training methods are used.
courses.condition:
Prerequisite: THEA 175 or consent of instructor.
Acting majors only.

courses.name: The Comic Imagination
courses.condition:

courses.name: History of Theatre I
courses.detail: History of the drama and theatre of ancient Greece and Rome, the Middle Ages, and the Italian and English Renaissance.
courses.condition: Prerequisite: Junior standing or consent of instructor.

courses.name: Acting Studio I: Dynamics
courses.detail: Development of movement and voice skills for actors. Enrollment limited to Theatre majors.
courses.condition: Prerequisite: THEA 275, consent of chair of Acting Program, and concurrent registration in THEA 372, THEA 373, and THEA 374.

courses.name: Acting Studio I: Voice
courses.detail: Concentrated training in standard speech for the stage and the International Phonetic Alphabet. Enrollment limited to Theatre majors.
courses.condition: Prerequisite: THEA 275, consent of chair of Acting Program, and concurrent registration in THEA 371, THEA 373, and THEA 374.

courses.name: Acting Studio I: Movement
courses.detail: Concentrated training in movement skills and mask characterization. . Enrollment limited to Theatre majors.
courses.condition: Prerequisite: THEA 275, consent of chair of Acting Program, and concurrent registration in THEA 371, THEA 372, and THEA 374.

courses.name: Acting Studio I: Acting
courses.detail: Acting in realistic and naturalistic plays. A performance is given at the end of the term. Enrollment limited to Theatre majors.
courses.condition:
Prerequisite: THEA 275, consent of chair of Acting Program, and concurrent registration in THEA 371, THEA 372, and THEA 373.
Acting Majors only. Sophomore level and above.

courses.detail: Individual projects and problems.

courses.name: Individual Topics

courses.name: Undergraduate Group Seminar
courses.detail: Group exploration of specialized topics.
courses.condition: May be repeated in the same term to a maximum of 8 hours. May be repeated in subsequent terms to a maximum of 12 hours.

courses.name: Practicum II
courses.detail: Advanced practical work in acting; theatre management; dramaturgy and directing; and the design, construction, and handling of scenery, lighting, sound, properties, costumes, and makeup for public performance.
courses.condition: 1 to 3 undergraduate hours. 1 to 3 graduate hours. May be repeated to a maximum of 12 hours. Prerequisite: Enrollment limited to Theatre majors.

courses.name: Stage Management Workshop
courses.detail: Explores advanced topics in stage management focusing on practical applications of principles learned in earlier courses. Possible topics include: Touring Stage Management, Stage Managing Opera and Dance, and Production Management.
courses.condition: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. May be repeated in the same or separate terms to a maximum of 6 undergraduate hours or 8 graduate hours as topics vary. Prerequisite: THEA 445 and THEA 446.

courses.name: Directors Workshop
courses.detail: Seminar course exploring the role of the director in the collaborative process. Course may be repeated as topics will vary.
courses.condition: 3 undergraduate hours. 3 graduate hours. May be repeated to maximum of 6 undergraduate hours or 9 graduate hours. Prerequisite: THEA 212.

courses.detail: Advanced problems in scene design for period and style plays and development of professional portfolio.

courses.name: Leading Post-Perform Dialog
courses.detail: Study of the history, processes, and methods of leading discussions with social issues theatre audiences. Emphasis on the skills and techniques of facilitators/peer educators; artistic considerations; function and application of the dramaturg; and practical experience through facilitation of social issues theatre dialog.
courses.condition: Same as GWS 417. 4 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Prerequisite: Junior standing or above or consent of instructor.

courses.name: Devising Social Issues Theatre
courses.detail: Focuses on the role of the artist as 'cultural worker' through devising theatre in a community-based context that is explicitly concerned with social and/or health-related issues. While there is substantial research, reading and critique involved, the overall experience will be that of rigorously composing theatrical work vital to the community.
courses.condition: Same as GWS 418. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

courses.name: CAD Drafting for the Stage
courses.detail: Study and application of computer-aided design techniques for scenery construction and design, focusing on the use of AutoCAD to create technical drawings for theatre.
courses.condition: 3 undergraduate hours. 3 graduate hours. May not be repeated for credit. Prerequisite: THEA 425; enrollment limited to Theatre majors or by consent of instructor.

courses.name: Advanced Lighting Design
courses.detail: Lighting design for the proscenium, arena, and thrust stage. Enrollment limited to Theatre majors.
courses.condition: 3 undergraduate hours. No graduate credit. Prerequisite: THEA 231.

courses.name: History of Decor
courses.detail: Historical and comparative survey of designs, motifs, and forms of decor in the West. Emphasis on the relation between research and design for the stage. Enrollment limited to Theatre majors.
courses.condition: 3 undergraduate hours. 3 graduate hours. Prerequisite: THEA 222.

courses.name: Scene Painting
courses.detail: Techniques and practice of scene painting; lab time required.
courses.condition: 2 undergraduate hours. 2 graduate hours. Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.

courses.name: Technical Direction
courses.detail: Advanced studies in technical direction and theatre production organization.
courses.condition: 3 undergraduate hours. 3 graduate hours. Prerequisite: THEA 223 or consent of instructor.

courses.name: Unknown Course
courses.detail:
Unknown course.

courses.condition: Unknown

courses.name: Convergence Design II
courses.detail: Environments: At the overlap of theatre, architecture, and media are a growing number of convergent environments and alternative spaces. This course expands on the elements of convergence design with a strong focus on the design and installation of light for the built environment, from theatres to casinos to museums.
courses.condition: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Prerequisite: THEA 231, THEA 423, THEA 431.

courses.name: Unknown Course
courses.detail:
Unknown course.
Search courses.illinois.edu for more info
courses.condition: Unknown

courses.name: Convergence Design III
courses.detail: Explorations: Expands on the elements and environments of convergent lighting design with a strong focus on the various forms of digital expression including video production, computer-based sketching and storyboarding, and projection design for live performance and installations.
courses.condition: 3 undergraduate hours. 3 graduate hours. Prerequisite: THEA 231, THEA 423, THEA 431, THEA 432.

courses.name: Professional Lighting Systems
courses.detail: Practical study of state-of-the-art lighting technology for the theatre, using the facilities of the Krannert Center for the Performing Arts. In-depth study of lighting control systems and programming, instrument maintenance, special effects, and the role of the master electrician in production.
courses.condition: 2 undergraduate hours. 2 graduate hours. May not be repeated for credit.

courses.name: Software for Lighting Design
courses.detail: Practical study of lighting design software currently used in the professional theatre and the entertainment industry. As technology evolves and new software developed, software programs will be added. Accommodating upgrades may necessitate offering the course every other year.
courses.condition: 2 undergraduate hours. 2 graduate hours. May be repeated to a maximum of 4 hours. Prerequisite: THEA 231 and THEA 425.

courses.name: Stage Mechanics II
courses.detail: Examines newly accepted and developing techniques and materials used in constructing and rigging stage scenery with emphasis on metalworking. Enrollment limited to Theatre majors.
courses.condition: 3 undergraduate hours. 3 graduate hours.

courses.name: Stage Mechanics III
courses.detail: Study in advanced scenery methods and materials, including advanced woodworking, plastic-craft, and rigging. Enrollment limited to Theatre majors.
courses.condition: 3 undergraduate hours. 3 graduate hours. Prerequisite: THEA 126.

courses.name: Unknown Course
courses.detail:
Unknown course.
Search courses.illinois.edu for more info
courses.condition: Unknown

courses.name: Costume Rendering
courses.detail: Studio course in costume rendering techniques: analysis of costume figure, rendering of fabrics, exploration of various rendering media. Enrollment limited to Theatre majors.
courses.condition: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.

courses.name: Management Seminar
courses.detail: Addresses production and management issues surrounding Theater Department and KCPA productions. Guest speakers provide professional points of view on various management topics.
courses.condition: 1 undergraduate hour. 1 graduate hour. May be repeated in separate terms to a maximum of 6 undergraduate or 6 graduate hours.

courses.name: Principles of Stage Management
courses.detail: Studies in the principles and the craft of stage management. Enrollment limited to Theatre majors.
courses.condition:
3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Prerequisite: Minimum of sophomore standing in a Theatre curriculum.
Consent of instructor needed for non-majors.

courses.name: Theatre Sound Technology
courses.detail: Exploration of audio production techniques and equipment, as related to theatre sound. Related topics include acoustics, electronics, and music.
courses.condition: 3 undergraduate hours. 3 graduate hours. Prerequisite: Enrollment limited to junior, senior or graduate theatre majors.

courses.name: Audio Production
courses.detail: Project-based study of professional techniques in audio recording, mixing, and editing for music, theatre, and film production, utilizing current digital technology.
courses.condition: 2 undergraduate hours. 2 graduate hours. May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours. Prerequisite: THEA 453.

courses.name: Sound Systems
courses.detail: Project-based study of professional techniques in sound system applications and design for sound reinforcement in music, theatre, and architectural applications.
courses.condition: 2 undergraduate hours. 2 graduate hours. May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours. Prerequisite: THEA 453.

courses.name: Acting Studio III: Dynamics
courses.detail: Continuing development of movement and voice skills for actors. Enrollment limited to Theatre majors.
courses.condition: 1 undergraduate hour. No graduate credit. Prerequisite: THEA 375, THEA 376, THEA 377 and THEA 378, and concurrent registration in THEA 472, THEA 473 and THEA 474.

courses.name: Acting Studio III: Voice
courses.detail: Advanced training in voice and speech for the stage with emphasis on classic texts. Enrollment limited to Theatre majors.
courses.condition: 2 undergraduate hours. No graduate credit. Prerequisite: THEA 375, THEA 376, THEA 377 and THEA 378, and concurrent registration in THEA 471, THEA 473 and THEA 474.

courses.name: Acting Studio III: Movement
courses.detail: Training in stage combat, sword, and rapier. Enrollment limited to Theatre majors.
courses.condition: 2 undergraduate hours. No graduate credit. Prerequisite: THEA 375, THEA 376, THEA 377 and THEA 378, and concurrent registration in THEA 471, THEA 472 and THEA 474.

courses.name: Acting Studio III: Acting
courses.detail: Acting in Shakespearean and other Elizabethan, Jacobean, and Caroline drama. A performance is given at the end of the term. Enrollment limited to Theatre majors.
courses.condition: 3 undergraduate hours. No graduate credit. Prerequisite: THEA 375, THEA 376, THEA 377 and THEA 378, and concurrent enrollment in THEA 471, THEA 472 and THEA 473.

courses.name: Professional Internship
courses.detail: Professional work with an approved host theatre or institution in an area related to the student's academic program; exposure to and participation in professional theatre. Full documentation and approval of internship activities required.
courses.condition: 0 to 14 undergraduate hours. 0 to 12 graduate hours. Approved for S/U grading only. May be repeated in the same or subsequent terms, if topics vary. Prerequisite: Junior, senior, or graduate standing in Theatre; consent of Internship Coordinator.

courses.name: Colloquium Design & Theat Tech
courses.detail: Projects in design for the theatre or in theatre technology, including stage scenery, costuming, lighting, makeup, projections, and sound and stage systems.
courses.condition: May be repeated to a maximum of 32 hours. Prerequisite: Enrollment limited to graduate students in theatre design and technology.

courses.name: Seminar in Theatre History
courses.detail: Studies in the history of the theatre.
courses.condition: May be repeated to a maximum of 16 hours. Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.

courses.name: Colloquium in Acting: Dynamics
courses.detail: Intensive professional training in voice and movement skills for the actor.
courses.condition: May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours. Prerequisite: Enrollment limited to graduate acting students; concurrent registration in THEA 572, THEA 573 and THEA 574.

courses.name: Colloquium in Acting: Voice
courses.detail: Intensive professional training in voice and speech for the actor.
courses.condition: May be repeated to a maximum of 12 hours. Prerequisite: Enrollment limited to graduate acting students; concurrent registration in THEA 571, THEA 573 and THEA 574.

courses.name: Colloquium in Acting: Movement
courses.detail: Intensive professional training in movement and stage combat for the actor.
courses.condition: May be repeated to a maximum of 12 hours. Prerequisite: Enrollment limited to graduate acting students; concurrent registration in THEA 571, THEA 572 and THEA 574.

courses.name: Colloquium in Acting: Acting
courses.detail: Intensive professional training in acting with a different focus each term on a particular style of dramatic literature.
courses.condition: May be repeated to a maximum of 18 hours. Prerequisite: Enrollment limited to graduate acting students; concurrent registration in THEA 571, THEA 572 and THEA 573.

courses.name: Special Problems
courses.detail: Individual research in selected topics by arrangement with the instructor.
courses.condition: 0 to 8 graduate hours. No professional credit. Approved for Letter and S/U grading. May be repeated up to 72 hours if topics vary. Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.

courses.name: Creative Project
courses.detail: Open to MFA candidates in theatre only.
courses.condition: Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.

courses.name: Thesis Research
courses.condition: Approved for S/U grading only. May be repeated. Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.

courses.name: Mgmt of Innov and Technology
courses.condition: Same as BADM 367. See BADM 367.

courses.name: Business Process Modeling
courses.condition: Same as BADM 460. See BADM 460.

courses.name: Intro to Translation Studies
courses.detail: Introduction to translation as an academic discipline and professional field through a series of texts in translation. Explores the ways in which texts, images, and ideas move across cultures, across time, across languages, and through different art forms; to elevate the students' appreciation of literature and other art forms; and get acquainted with the complexities of a work of art as a cultural manifestation and with the ways in which various artists, writers and translators have attempted to recreate these complexities in other languages and cultures.
courses.condition:
Prerequisite: Students must have met the University of Illinois foreign language requirement.
This course satisfies the General Education Criteria in Fall 2016 for a UIUC: Literature and the Arts course

courses.name: Translation, Theory & Practice
courses.condition: Same as GER 403. See GER 403.

courses.name: Translation for Professions
courses.detail: Develop the practice of "instrumental" translation skills in a variety of technical domains, including translation for new media, medical and legal translation, and localization. Focuses on the technical, cultural and terminological problems that characterize localization and globalization as governing criteria of translation in today's knowledge economy.
courses.condition: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Prerequisite: Departmental approval. Six semesters of foreign language study.

courses.name: Terminology and CAT
courses.detail: The theoretical and practical aspects of terminology studies, as well as the computer skills required of a translator in today's Language Service Provider (LSP) environment, mastery of a variety of computer-assisted translation (CAT) tools and the SDL Trados suite. Practical applications of terminology work include advanced Internet research for translation work, terminology "mining" exercises, construction of terminology databases and management of those databases. Terminology theory is situated within the field of translation studies as derived from the discipline of linguistics.
courses.condition: 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Prerequisite: Departmental approval. Six semesters of foreign language study.

courses.name: Translation Tools & Practice
courses.detail: An advanced tools course that provides familiarity with a range of CAT tools and also localization software. Combines the most up-to-date theoretical studies on translation/localization practices with hands-on activities aimed at having students understand and reflect, by using the tools, on the language, culture- and content-bound issues that translation professionals face when adapting content from an L1 to an L2 culture. Standard industry tolls will be used in class and for assignments. The class will be structured into three main units: Corpus Generation, Website/Software Localization and Machine Translation.
courses.condition:
3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.
Students must be enrolled in the MA in Translation and Interpreting or in the program in Translation Studies (certificate or planned minor).

courses.name: Spanish/English Translation
courses.condition: Same as SPAN 410. See SPAN 410.

courses.name: Arabic-English Translation
courses.condition: Same as ARAB 413. See ARAB 413.

courses.name: History of Translation
courses.condition: Same as CLCV 430, CWL 430, ENGL 486, GER 405, SLAV 430, and SPAN 436. See SLAV 430.

courses.name: Conference Interpreting
courses.detail: Introduction to conference interpreting as its main theoretical concepts, including what is interpreting, interpreting as process, and what is conference interpreting. Core skills will be introduced and practiced, such as understanding the spoken language and language analysis techniques, acquisition of subject matter knowledge, terminology management, verbal expression skills, interpreting in practice, and mastery of the technologist of the interpreter booth. Interpreting practice in the student's language pairs will be a part of the course.
courses.condition: Prerequisite: Admission to the Masters in Translation and Interpretation.

courses.name: Translation Methods and Ethics
courses.detail: Introduction to basic research methods in translation studies, including both traditional library research and innovative online research techniques for the MA in Translation and Interpretation. Also addresses ethical issues for translators and interpreters in different specializations, including legal, medical, diplomatic, and technical translation. Basic business practices and etiquette for translators and interpreters will be introduced.
courses.condition: Prerequisite: Admission to the Masters in Translation and Interpretation.

courses.name: Special Topics in Translation
courses.detail: Covers topics of special interests to rising professional translators in the three areas of specialization of the MA in Translation and Interpreting: Applied Literary Translation, Translation for the Professions and Interpreting. Examples of topics may include: Translation for Government, Literary Translation, Translation and Digital Humanities.
courses.condition:
May be repeated in separate terms for a maximum of 8 hours.
Graduate students in the MA in Translation and Interpreting and the graduate certificate or planned graduate minor in translation.

courses.name: Technical Systems in Agr
courses.detail: Examples, problems, discussions, and laboratory exercises pointing to present and potential engineering applications in agriculture; emphasis on power and machinery, soil and water control, electricity, and structures.

courses.name: Basics of CAD
courses.detail: Introduction to Computer Aided Drawing and Design (CAD). Application of two and three dimensional CAD tools in construction systems for creating project plans, structures and building floor plans with fixtures and layers representing electrical and plumbing configurations. Self-paced learning through on-line tutorials with instructor guidance.
courses.condition: Prerequisite: TSM 100.

courses.name: Undergraduate Open Seminar
courses.detail: Open seminar or experimental course on a topic in technical systems management.
courses.condition: May be repeated to a maximum of 12 hours.

courses.name: Materials and Construction Sys
courses.detail: Selection, use, and maintenance of hand and power tools; shop safety; selection of building and roofing materials; concrete masonry construction; and site preparation. Includes laboratory. Priority is given to technical systems management majors.

courses.name: Metallurgy & Welding Process
courses.detail: Selecting and using metal-arc, inert-gas, submerged arc, oxyacetylene welding and plasma cutting processes for construction and maintenance. Includes laboratory.
courses.condition: Additional fees may apply. See Class Schedule.

courses.name: Off-Campus Internship
courses.detail: Supervised off-campus experience in a field directly pertaining to technical systems management.
courses.condition: May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours. Prerequisite: Sophomore standing and consent of instructor.

courses.name: Undergrad Research or Thesis
courses.detail: Individual research, special problems, thesis, development and/or design work under the supervision of an appropriate member of the faculty.
courses.condition: May be repeated to a maximum of 12 hours. Prerequisite: Sophomore standing, cumulative GPA of 2.5 or above at the time the activity is arranged, and consent of instructor.

courses.name: Humanity in the Food Web
courses.detail: The human food web is the complex network of technologies, environments, people, and social institutions that produces, processes, and distributes the world's food supply. Students will study the food webs of the past, present, and future and will explore various human roles, including their own, in the global technology-environment-society-food system. Course topics include domestication, mechanization, urbanization, the green revolution, biotechnology, food safety, the environment, and appropriate technologies for developing countries.
courses.condition:
Additional fees may apply. See Class Schedule.
This course satisfies the General Education Criteria in Fall 2016 for a UIUC: Hist&Philosoph Perspect course , and UIUC: Advanced Composition course

courses.name: Environ Control & HVAC Systems
courses.detail: Introduction to heating, ventilating, and air-conditioning (HVAC) systems for building environment control. Topics include: psychrometrics, basic calculation of heating and cooling loads, human comfort and ventilation requirements, typical HVAC and control systems.

courses.name: UG Honors Research or Thesis
courses.detail: Individual research, special problems, thesis, development and/or design work under the direction of the Honors advisor.
courses.condition: May be repeated to a maximum of 12 hours. Prerequisite: Junior standing, admission to the ACES Honors Program, and consent of instructor.

courses.name: Ag Health-Illnesses Prevention
courses.detail: Overview of occupational illnesses and diseases in the agricultural industry and its practicies. Hazards within agricultural production are examined and potential hazards to non-farm populations and those interacting with production personnel are explored. Agricultural industry practices are summarized and potential human health effects of specific practices identified. Specific preventative measures are outlined to reduce exposures and remediate exposure symptoms. Interaction with health/medical professionals is on-going during the semester to familiarize students with medical procedures pertinent to agricultural occupational medicine.
courses.condition: 3 undergraduate hours. 3 graduate hours.

courses.name: Project Management
courses.condition: Same as ABE 430. See ABE 430.

courses.name: Elec Computer Ctrl Sys
courses.detail: Microcomputer and electrical control applications; electrical fundamentals; solid-state devices; relays; biosensors; motor types and characteristics; three-phase power; logic devices; analog/digital convertors; and interfacing for agricultural control applications. Includes laboratory.
courses.condition: 3 undergraduate hours. 3 graduate hours.

courses.name: Renewable Energy Applications
courses.detail: Renewable energy sources and applications, including solar, geothermal, wind, and biomass. Environmental consequences of energy conversion including how renewable energy can reduce air pollution and global climate change. Economics of alternative energy systems.
courses.condition: 3 undergraduate hours. 3 graduate hours. Credit is not given for both TSM 438 and ABE 436. Prerequisite: Junior, senior, or graduate standing required.

courses.name: Precision Agric Technology
courses.detail: Practices and equipment used in precision agriculture. Global positioning systems; geographic information systems; mapping; grid sampling of soil fertility and physical properties; yield monitoring; remote sensing; variable-rate technologies.
courses.condition: 3 undergraduate hours. 3 graduate hours.

courses.name: Independent Study
courses.detail: Individual research, special problems, thesis, development and/or design work under the supervision of a faculty member.
courses.condition: 1 to 4 undergraduate hours. 1 to 4 graduate hours. May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours. Prerequisite: consent of instructor.

courses.name: Graduate Research I
courses.detail: First of a two-course sequence (with TSM 502) for graduate students in Technical Systems Management. Prepares students to perform successfully in a research environment and to develop skills in teaching. Topics to be covered include research methodology, teaching methods, lecture preparation and delivery, critical review of scientific articles, peer review and publishing, mentoring and peer relationships, time management, and intellectual property.

courses.name: Graduate Seminar
courses.detail: Presentations of thesis research by graduate students; other presentations on teaching or current research issues related to technical systems management.
courses.condition: Approved for S/U grading only. May be repeated to a maximum of six times.

courses.name: Independent Study
courses.detail: Individual investigations or studies of any phases of technical systems management selected by the student and approved by the advisor and the faculty member who will supervise the study.
courses.condition: May be repeated in the same or separate terms if topics vary to a maximum of 6 hours. Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.

courses.name: Thesis Research
courses.detail: Individual research in the various areas of technical systems management under the supervision of faculty members.
courses.condition: Approved for S/U grading only. May be repeated in separate terms.

courses.name: Elementary Turkish I
courses.detail: Mastery of Turkish alphabet and phonetics; elementary formal grammar and the development of reading and writing skills; and conversation in the formal noncolloquial style. Participation in the laboratory is required.

courses.name: Intermediate Turkish I
courses.detail: Continuation of TURK 202; emphasis on the development of appropriate reading, writing, speaking, and comprehension skills in Standard and Colloquial Turkish, with increased attention to ordinary written texts.
courses.condition: 4 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Prerequisite: TURK 202 or equivalent.

courses.name: Unknown Course
courses.detail:
Unknown course.
Search courses.illinois.edu for more info
courses.condition: Unknown

courses.name: Advanced Turkish I
courses.detail: Third-year Turkish with emphasis on conversational fluency and on increased ability in reading and comprehending texts, including newspaper prose and Turkish cultural materials. Course will also deal with the advanced level grammar found in such texts.
courses.condition: 3 undergraduate hours. 3 graduate hours. Prerequisite: TURK 404 or equivalent.

courses.name: Unknown Course
courses.detail:
Unknown course.
Search courses.illinois.edu for more info
courses.condition: Unknown

courses.name: Basic Ukrainian I
courses.detail: Oral and written work on basic pronunciation, grammar, and vocabulary. For students with no previous study of Ukrainian.

courses.name: Undergraduate Open Seminar
courses.condition: May be repeated.

courses.name: Second-Year Ukrainan I
courses.detail: Completion of grammar, oral drills, and written exercises.
courses.condition: Prerequisite: UKR 102 or equivalent.

courses.name: Unknown Course
courses.detail:
Unknown course.

courses.condition: Unknown

courses.name: Introduction to City Planning
courses.detail: Provides an introduction to urban and regional planning by examining the history of American urbanization, the evolution of American planning thought and practice, and contemporary issues and planning approaches.
courses.condition: Students must register for one lab-discussion and one lecture section.

courses.name: Undergraduate Open Seminar
courses.condition: May be repeated.

courses.name: Planning in Action
courses.detail: Introduces students to different career paths open to urban studies and planning majors. Students interact with professionals and take part in hands-on activities related to different concentration areas: sustainability, policy & planning, social justice and global cities.

courses.name: Cities: Planning & Urban Life
courses.detail: Provides a broad introduction to social science theories and analysis methods to examine how people, communities, and governments plan a city. Draws upon theories and methods of several social science disciplines including economics, geography, political science, anthropology and sociology. Includes hands-on application of fundamental analysis techniques.
courses.condition: Credit is not given for both UP 203 and UP 204. Prerequisite: UP 101.

courses.name: Environmental Economics
courses.condition:
Same as ACE 210, ECON 210, ENVS 210, and NRES 210. See ACE 210.
This course satisfies the General Education Criteria in Fall 2016 for a UIUC Social Sciences course

courses.name: Local Planning, Gov't and Law
courses.detail: Provides students with a basic understanding of the governmental structure, legal aspects, and practice of local municipal planning, with special emphasis on case law, constitutional principles, zoning, subdivision regulations and comprehensive planning. Gives an introduction for students interested in pursuing more advanced studies in land use law and local government planning.

courses.name: Social Inequality and Planning
courses.detail: How are inequalities produced and contested in an urban environment? This course examines this question by analyzing how the urban landscape shapes and is shaped by race, class, and gender inequalities. Uses comparative cases to explore successful intervention, both from formal and informal, across multiple scales from the local to the global.
courses.condition: This course satisfies the General Education Criteria in Fall 2016 for a UIUC Social Sciences course

courses.name: Communication for Planners
courses.detail: Integrates written, verbal, and graphic communication techniques into planning and analysis. Activities simulate professional situations where students develop skills and pieces of broader arguments and synthesize them into final products.
courses.condition:
Prerequisite: Completion of campus Composition I general education requirement.
This course satisfies the General Education Criteria in Fall 2016 for a UIUC: Advanced Composition course

courses.name: The Modern American City
courses.detail: Explore the transformation of the American city in its journey from abandonment to renewed growth. Cities today are sites of rapid change and experimentation with new ideas for how people can and should live. This course examines the resurgence of American cities, the challenges they face, and their transformation in the 21st century. Each week, class will focus on a different aspect of the modern American city--work, housing, globalization, high finance--and explore its promises, challenges, and implications for the future.

courses.name: Economic Development Planning
courses.detail: Public-private-partnerships in urban economic development, including study of potentials, problems, and projects; financing urban economic development through federal grant programs, tax increment financing, and other means.

courses.name: Planning Internship
courses.detail: Professionally supervised field experience in public and private planning or development agencies. Designed to introduce students to professional employment and actual planning practice. Students work in an agency of their own choice, subject to departmental approval, either during the summer session or part-time during a regular term. At least two weeks of full-time employment or its equivalent is required for each term hour of credit to a maximum of 4 hours. Summary reports are submitted by both employer and student.
courses.condition: Approved for S/U grading only. May be repeated. Counts toward the Capstone Experience Requirement. Prerequisite: Upper division undergraduate standing in urban planning.

courses.name: Undergraduate Project
courses.detail: Special projects and applied research related to real world urban problems and professional practice. One credit hour requires approximately 80 hours of work.
courses.condition: May be repeated up to 3 hours. Counts toward the Capstone Experience Requirement. Prerequisite: Upper division standing in Urban Planning and consent of Capstone advisor.

courses.name: Watershed Ecology and Planning
courses.detail: Uses the watershed as the basic organizing concept in environmental planning and management; methods for assessing watershed boundaries, soils, land use, and groundwater system processes and developing plans for watershed protection. Emphasizes ecological implications of patterns of land use on functional and qualitative aspects of watershed systems. All-day field trip required.
courses.condition: 4 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Prerequisite: Should have a previous course in environmental science.

courses.name: GIS for Planners
courses.detail: Detailed introduction to the design and use of computerized geographic information systems, focusing on their significance for planning. Emphasizes GIS within an institutional setting, covering not only fundamental technical concepts, but also organizational, management, and legal issues. Students will be introduced to GIS applications and products through readings, videos, demonstrations, and exercises. Computer laboratory work is included.
courses.condition:
4 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Prerequisite: Upper division undergaraduate or graduate standing.
Students must register for one lab and one lecture section, except in summer terms when labs are not offered.

courses.name: Plng for Historic Preservation
courses.detail: Historic preservation in the context of urban planning, including legal issues and ordinances, economic incentives, comprehensive plans and preservation plans, public participation, media relations, and more. Students will conduct a building survey including research and architectural descriptions for an on-going project in Urbana. Tours of local preservation projects.
courses.condition: 4 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Prerequisite: At least junior standing.

courses.name: Community Development in the Global South
courses.detail: Introduces students to the main theoretical frameworks and conceptual building blocks of urban and community development in the Global South. It helps students to develop critical grassroots focused understanding of the approaches to development planning, the notion of community participation and empowerment, and the role of various actors including the non-government organizations and the community-based groups.
courses.condition: 4 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

courses.name: Urban Design and Planning
courses.detail: Concepts and techniques of urban analysis, plan making, and implementation essential for effective interdisciplinary work in urban design.
courses.condition: 4 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Prerequisite: Senior standing.

courses.name: Urban Transportation Planning
courses.detail: Role of transportation in urban development and planning; characteristics of urban-person transportation systems and methods of analysis and forecasting of urban-person transportation demand; transportation systems management and capital improvement programming; and emphasis on the needs and activities of metropolitan planning organizations.
courses.condition: Same as CEE 417. 4 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.

courses.name: Disasters and Urban Planning
courses.detail: Introduction to the role of urban planners in preparing for and rebuilding after disasters. Emphasizes U.S. planning practice, with particular attention to the role of local government. Includes basic U.S. emergency management laws and framework, local mitigation planning, and post-disaster recovery planning.
courses.condition: 4 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Prerequisite: Graduate standing, senior in Urban Planning, or consent of instructor.

courses.name: Land Use Planning Workshop
courses.detail: Small group field work applying principles and techniques to specific land use problems in selected jurisdictions.
courses.condition: 4 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Prerequisite: UP 211, senior or graduate standing, or consent of instructor.

courses.name: Sustainable Planning Workshop
courses.detail: Focuses on applying sustainable planning principles in a real world setting. Readings and research into indices of sustainable development, sustainable urbanism, and related literature help establish parameters for resolving a local planning project. Course is a hybrid workshop with portions of the semester spent on reading, research, and application working with a local planning agency.
courses.condition: 4 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours. Prerequisite: UP 136 and UP 205, senior or graduate standing, or consent of instructor.

courses.name: Unknown Course
courses.detail:
Unknown course.
